BAv-fzcerzyxWcE7JIYAFQ.text: Always have had awesome service. The curries here are decent, but I don't think it's easy to mess up a Thai curry, unless the restaurant is baaad. However, this place is not my fave in Pittsburgh, nowhere close. I would rank, Smiling Banana Leaf, Thai Cuisine, Green Mango and then may be BB. Well, after that remains the blah places (ahem Thai Place). In our latest venture, we asked for an 8, for each of our entrees. One tasted like a 3 another like a zero. The flavors were good, but nothing be wow-ing about, specially at that price-point. I think BB tries too hard to be the "upscale" Thai place and misses out on the "good food" part. I say focus on the food, not the frills.

VmzFYTtXre-JuOnMePqMmA.text: Our waitress was really friendly and gave us good advice on what to get. The Mai tai  was really good but kinda pricey $8. We got the padthai and duck curry. Both were delicious and so filling that we had leftovers to take home. The atmosphere is really nice and is bigger than it looks from the outside.

r93pDFjNmBGy25Y-2cSILA.text: I visited with a friend last night and had a pretty good experience here.  The atmosphere is nice, it wasn't too loud, we were seated with no wait (around 7pm) and as another reviewer mentioned, their flatware is pretty darn cool.  The only thing that bugged me is that the lights kept flickering, but that's a pretty minor gripe.  The service was attentive without being intrusive.  Some of the appetizers seem pretty pricey, but it's only $3.50 for two spring rolls which were pretty good.  We split a pumpkin curry and the bean thread noodles, both with tofu.  I usually like my tofu crispier and pan-seared on the outside and theirs looked like it had barely touched the pan.  I also thought the sauce on the bean thread noodles was pretty bland and sparse.  But the pumpkin was melt-in-your-mouth delicious and the noodles were generally pretty good.  I've also tried a panang curry, which was delicious but the spice level of 6 was a bit much for me, and the pad thai, which was ok but a little bland.  It seems like the curries have much more flavors than the noodles, so maybe keep that in mind when ordering.  The total for the spring rolls and 2 entrees was $31 before tip.  Even though I wasn't blown away by the food, I am looking forward to coming back to try more.

4TGKr8eGuQ88qBmn2y9Puw.text: The best Thai place in Pittsburgh.This place is pretty crowded and the service is acceptable.But they have great Panang Tofu,Green curry and all other yummy veggie rolls.Their peanut sauce is great and i am actually running out of words because my mouth is watering :(    I would love to go to this place again,when i visit Pittsburgh.And for some reason the name  "Bangkok Balcony" seems very classy and attractive.My friend suggested this place,and i owe him one for this :)  -Smriti

AadUQpTCWT_BNlx1T08tHw.text: I've been to a lot of Thai restaurants, and Bangkok Balcony is a favorite in Pittsburgh.  Being a pumpkin lover, my first choice was obvious--the tofu pumpkin curry! And a good choice it was. Thick, hearty, very pumpkiny, and very spicy. Usually 8/10 is a comfortable level of spice for me, but this definitely got my sinuses going. No complaints from me! The portion was large and the dish was very heavy. The tofu helped to balance it out a little, but I still had a lot to take home. Still, this had to be one of my favorite Thai dishes anywhere, ever.  Another of my favorites here is the mussel fritters. It's basically a bunch of deep fried mussels on a bed of beansprouts with a Pad Thai-like sauce. Delicious!  Their Panang curry, unfortunately, is thin and bland, and I also wasn't too impressed with the fresh spring rolls. They weren't terrible, but you can get much better at most other Thai places in the 'burgh. But the pumpkin curry...! I gotta give the place props.

qtuf4jKOh9adodxCz1eu5g.text: Every time I go to Pittsburgh and I want thai food (which is often) we come here. The food is not terrible. The pad thai is a little on the sweet side and I feel like they play it safe with flavors. The decor is a plus and they are very well equipped to handle large families and groups. Check it out though.

sLP6AH6bIBQW1ussIipRyw.text: My family and I were looking for a last-minute place to dine after our trip to the Carnegie Museum of Natural History one evening.  We had never been to Bangkok Balcony and decided to give it a try.  I was impressed not only with the food, but also the service, the facilities and the atmosphere.  Our server was very efficient and friendly; our food arrived in a timely manner and all the dishes were excellent.  We all eat Thai food fairly often and we thought this cuisine was up there with the best.  During the early part of our meal, the whole restaurant was entertained by two dancers dressed in traditional costume and dancing to recorded music.  Although I've never experienced live dancing in a Thai restaurant before, I thought the music and dance to be very calming and an enjoyable addition to our evening.  Finally, the restroom facilities were clean and hygienic, which I find to be very telling of the type of management.  My only caveat worth mentioning was that the lighting was incredibly dim; it made for a difficult reading of the menu.  But that's hardly a drawback considering the rest of our meal was so pleasant.  Overall, it was a great experience and I'd recommend it to any of my friends who are in the area.

9Fl6twZ3sL4wCadm6QxTLw.text: Reasonable atmosphere and prices at one of the few Thai places that serve wine and beer in the East End. The Green curry is good and the Pud is excellent.

FDGVA38gOcLQssqDf8UfHg.text: I give Bangkok Balcony 3 stars, bec. I think generally it's one of the more  overrated restaurants. The food isn't bad, it just isn't the best Thai in the city. Portions are on the small side and the restaurant is pretty noisy. I've been there at least 3 times. The service can be uneven to the point of really horrible.  It's also not the freshest or most authentic Thai food in the city. The Massaman curry had a strange sour taste. The green curry was a little better. The coconut soup was okay, but was an extremely small portion. The pad thai was not bad, but I don't go to a restaurant to eat street food. It was the typical oily sweet mess of noodles you find it most places. I would not recommend this place for a romantic dinner.

d0nl4peO12sybjHBk0AHPA.text: My wife & I have been here twice now & both times were very happy with our food. I highly recommend the yellow curry. It's so sweet, but with a slight kick... just right! I somewhat agree with previous reviewers that the service wasn't lightning fast, but our waitress was friendly & it wasn't expecting "fast food," so wasn't disappointed. Finally, while the fact that this place is on the 2nd story makes it a bit tricky to spot the first time, the view is nice as you can watch people stroll around the shops at Squirrel Hill. We'll definitely be returning to this place when we're in Pittsburgh again.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Bangkok Balcony as seen from the sidewalk (be sure to look up!)

pOhIniSf-EU0v44g93EJ_w.text: The atmosphere is okay, but the food is average at best for Pittsburgh Thai. Prices are relatively high for what you get and it's not BYOB like many Thai Restaurants in the area. Luckily we have lots of other good Thai to choose from.

xQYyPtoFdX2W6FDcx8uCmQ.text: Bangkok Balcony may be deserving of 3 stars, but the fact that it's been voted best Thai in Pittsburgh - well, we expected more.  Crab Rangoon, one of the popular apps was devoid of any crab flavor or noticeable chunks.  Instead, it was mostly just cream cheese.  And it's accompanied by the typical out-of-the-bottle neon orange corn syrup sauce.  Would it be that hard to mix up an original dipping sauce?  Green Curry with Thai Spaghetti was tasty, but the noodles seemed overcooked and mushy.  Unless they are supposed to be that way, it didn't add anything to the dish.   The curry was good, with a fair amount of shrimp included.  My wife had the Tofu with Eggplant, and it too was pretty tasty, but not special.  The tofu seemed overly fried, with no tenderness.    As far as Thai goes - this is just your average Thai place.  What makes it Best in the Burgh is still a mystery to us.  We don't really see the need to go back - especially since the prices really don't reflect the quality of the food.

aD2yk_Xn4D36gxJOTQilfA.text: *3.5 stars* Came here with a Thai craving and it was a good fill :) The staff was nice, the restaurant was quite large and we were sat right near the window of the 'balcony' with a lovely view of snowy Squirrel Hill. We asked if they had BYOB since we were actually planning to go to a BYOB restaurant, but the cork fee was $15 so it wasn't worth it. They do have a nice bar, so that's completely understandable. I got the usual, and now I kind of consider myself a pumpkin curry expert since it's the 4th place I have sampled it in PGH. My boyfriend got a sweet potato basil curry with chicken. Both of our heat levels were pretty weak, I ordered a 5 and got more like a 2, and boyfriend agreed. But overall the food was quite yummy, although mine literally had only 2-3 pieces of tofu, which was kind of disappointing.  I would definitely come back here though!

Db4zw9P9_GOhSExOPjm3VA.text: Today my gf and I had the pineapple fried rice which is one of my favorite dishes. My gf decided it was the best she has ever had after searching all of the local Asian restaurants for a better one. Highly recommend. The pumpkin curry is also delicious.

lSNQQyz-ba7GQyXSZ1ThZg.text: I've been in Pittsburgh a while and I've been missing good Thai food, so I decided to try Bangkok Balcony (without expecting very much).  Overall, the food was okay (not as bad as I'd feared, but nothing special).  The service was nice and it's a nice spot to dine (if you get a seat by the window overseeing the street).  However, I didn't care much for the decor or the table setting.

-_K9KqNH0hJqu-bCxgkhdg.text: Bangkok Balcony was really my first foray into Thai food, and it set the bar high. The environment is relatively elegant (particularly for the Squirrel Hill area) and the food is delicious. I particularly remember having great service; some the waiters even started to recognize me, and I didn't go that often! (I also remember the neat, weighted silverware, but that doesn't exactly figure into the review...) Anyway, I was a big fan of this place for all 4 years of my college experience. Definitely recommend if you're looking for a non-hole-in-the-wall Asian food experience.

2CCF6jTSctMjZGd0KNNmOg.text: Bangkok Balcony is located in Squirrel Hill.  If you're walking on Forbes Avenue, hang a left at 5846, and head upstairs.  I can remember my first time there; I didn't expect to see a larger sized restaurant.  Seating capacity is around 75 people, with additional chairs at the bar.  The atmosphere is nice and uncomplicated- if you get a seat near the window you can people-watch everyone on the Avenue below.  The decor is nice, but not memorable.  My impression was that more attention was paid to the seating layout rather than space and interior design.  We ordered drinks first; a ginger ale for me (lame right?) and a blood-orange martini for my girlfriend.  The martini was excellent- very tart and strong; no skimping on the vodka here!  We also ordered an appetizer; Fresh Rolls- fried tofu, rice noodles, carrots, lettuce, mint basil, and rice paper served with brown dipping sauce and crushed peanuts.  I've had fresh rolls (or spring rolls) at many different restaurants, and these were just ok.  The one thing that really stood out was the thickness of the rice paper.  They were difficult to cut...too many sheets of rice paper.  Summer rolls should be light and fresh...and easy to eat, these were not.  That being said, the sauce was good.  For our entrees: Praram Chicken; grilled chicken on a bed of steamed spinach with peanut curry sauce.  My girlfriend ordered the Green Curry Veggie Style:  broccoli, green beans, snow peas, eggplant, basil leaf, and bell pepper in a coconut milk and green curry sauce.  The chicken tender, and moist.  The spinach was flash sauteed, and not overdone.  What I really love about this dish is the addictiveness of the peanut sauce.  It has a bold flavor with hints of coconut and ginger.  The green curry was equally good.  In lieu of meat, my girlfriend decided to add tofu.  The tofu absorbed the flavors of the sauce quite well, as did the vegetables.  Her entree was also served with white rice that was cooked to a satisfactory doneness- not too mushy, with the grains of rice easily separating.  There are many choices here, especially if you're a vegetarian.  If you're a non-meat-eater you may want to consider: Spicy Tofu with Mixed Vegetables $11.95, Praram Tufu $10.95, Tofu Eggplant with Basil Leaf $11.95, Tofu Platter $11.95, and the Tofu with Bell Pepper Dish $11.95.  When ordering, be sure to specify degree of spiciness, from 1 to 10.  The wait staff at Bangkok Balcony is competent, just unenthusiastic.  Our orders were taken in a timely manner, and the food arrived correctly, but there just seemed to be something missing- almost as if they were disinterested and ready to leave before they started their shift.  The food at Bangkok balcony is good.  I wish they could re-work those Fresh Rolls!  Overall our experiences at this restaurant have been nice.  The food is consistently good, and you can always count on getting a table if you arrive before 6pm. Bangkok Balcony 5846 Forbes  Avenue Pittsburgh, PA 15217-1602 (412) 521-0728

jQcEMWtPyWe_DdZr2yyeMg.text: I use to frequent here often when i lived in Pittsburgh - it was one of my favorite thai places and the food was great +1 !   I practically tried out most of the menu here! One of the few places who can actually make it spicy enough for me +1.   Service was always good and great place to come with friends +1  Inside the place is nice and def looks swanky - however the menu prices are not, reasonable prices! +1

H5JDrt-1V15RFeE5_eFw_w.text: One of my favorite restaurants in Pittsburgh! Great food, good prices. Spring rolls, See-you-noodles, pineapple fried rice, and pad thai are my go to dishes! The dishes aren't fancy but I have gotten consistently great Thai food here for many years. Staff is nice. There is a parking garage on the corner of Forbes so its pretty convenient.

kkHWDRnZrdNUgSGzeIucVg.text: Not only is it a really nice looking restaurant, the food makes me very happy as well.  I've compared their Spicy Basil Noodle to all other thai places in town, trying to match BB's quality without success.  Thai Cuisine in Bloomfield is the only place that can come close to rivaling BB's crushing awesomeness.

GJFcSLfTKKv2KdFklDzxAg.text: Terrible. And I can say so with confidence because our group ordered 6 entrees for carryout, and not a single one was remotely good. At $14/entree and with 6 very hungry people, this was a huge disappointment.   What we had:   - coconut soup - lemongrass soup - basil leaf stir-fry - ginger stir-fry - panang curry - pineapple curry - rad-na - tofu eggplant with basil leaf  My gripes:   1. Coconut soup was too salty to be edible.  2. Tofu was the deep-fried kind, which meant it was dry and rubbery.   3. Curry was watery and thin, with barely a cup of vegetables per entree. For $14 an entree, this was totally unacceptable. Getting full by eating rice drowned in watery curry is not my idea of a good meal, even at half the price.   4. Stir-fries all tasted exactly the same. At one point, I thought we had ordered two ginger stir-fries. Then halfway through the meal, we found noodles in one of them - this, apparently, was the rad-na noodle dish. Same exact dish, but with noodles. Take note, y'all, this is THE definition of lazy cooking.   Conclusion: Avoid avoid avoid.

yg6kO-BiVnO7cmP1RmCHpQ.text: My companion and I were provided one of the three window tables, very nice, even though this was a gloomy, rainy evening.  The service shines at Bangkok Balcony.  Multiple servers could not have been more attentive; multiple quality checks were provided, and every visit brought a gracious woman with a broad smile.  If we should have needed anything, it would have been easy to get someone to provide it.  Our noodle dishes with chicken were delicious and I like that the level of spiciness can be specified.  I had a level 2; my companion ordered a 4; both were perfect for us.  My tofu soup and her spring roll appetizer were excellent.  The restaurant is not inexpensive; our entrees were $13.95 for a standard-size portion, but one gets what they pay for.    I recommend Bangkok Balcony to Thai food lovers.

ef7oEsGVevL1H4v1eCRWnw.text: When we don't want to sit in traffic back and forth to Bloomfield, this is our favorite place for Thai food in the East End. The food is consistently good. We like the noodles (pad thai and pad see ewe), Thai fried rice, and the curries (yellow, green, mussaman). The portions are generous, and they put lots of proteins and vegetables in too.   The spice levels match what you think they should be so if you like spice, go for it. We order a 5 or so, and it's usually about right for flavor without pain. If you want to reach for your drink every bit or so, you'll need an 8 or a 9. Our Thai server told us that she usually orders a 15, but that it does give her some heartburn.  The lunch specials are great, reasonably priced, and tons of food.  The atmosphere is great. We love the view although the tables by the window are two-tops so if you want the best tables go with a single friend or a date.  The service is excellent. The staff is attentive and efficient.

nfbVMDZjHFTSHCc8A-BOYg.text: Arrive at 10:00 PM and had a very delightful meal with my boy friend by the window. The food is definitely beyond average among all Thai restaurants in PGH. We had a seafood curry (3/5), a lemongrass soup with veggie (5/5), and a fish wrapped in the banana leaf (5/5). Seafood curry is not the name on the menu. I marked it down because seafood is always not a good option in PGH. Fish gets its full points for flavor, also some creativity. The soup is so basic, yet so good. The price is very reasonable and plus the nice ambience, which makes it a nice destination for lunch or dinner, with your friends or dates.

MGq6mWuIRp_eY0uaC_owgg.text: This place is one of my favorite Thai restaurants in the area because the service, atmosphere and food are always on point.  The quality of the food, speed food takes They're very consistent when it comes to quality of food and quick, attentive service.   Recommendations: See Ew noodles are amazing. I usually get 6 for spicy with tofu as my protein (the tofu are like sponges for the sauce) and it's simply delicious.    Green Curry is also great, especially if you love eggplant! Ask for extra eggplant, though, because they don't put a lot normally.

cwpCPyRDVdPdd4fC6skbBw.text: The food was tasty, the music was nice, but the only problem is that it smelled a bit strange when I got there, and $2:00 was too much for 3 shrimp with the tails still on. Good food, nice people, but overpriced.

F_nxUlAeieHd4J4sPJ2RIg.text: Food took almost 2 hours to be delivered. Called to check in after an hour and person answering phone wasn't apologetic. Food tasted like it had been made 2 hours ago. Enough good places in the area to not order from here again.

2MR9p56usrgSdgohaNg6dg.text: Had dinner with my family. Heard about it through a friend who goes there for lunch.  Started with and enjoyed the Singha beer. Delicious food, and very courteous, prompt and friendly service. Great ambience - very authentic. Will definitely go back soon.  It can be ranked as one if the best Thai restaurants in the Pittsburgh area. Strongly recommend.

eVtG7S77ROKcJWlsGEv7YQ.text: This is just a review of the food, as I only ordered delivery. I am new to the Sq Hill neighborhood and am hoping to find a good Thai restaurant. Maybe I am just spoiled from Smiling Banana Leaf, but this Thai food was just ehh. I ordered the Fresh Rolls and pumpkin curry with tofu, very spicy level. The rolls were okay. The curry however was not spicy whatsoever, there were 3 pieces of "pumpkin" which actually had no taste or color (like its typical yellow/green) and could very well have just been potatoes. The tofu is the airy kind that holds no flavor. Bottom line, I will not get Thai food here anymore and would be willing to make the trek across town to Smiling Banana Leaf. I guess I will give the other Thai restaurants in Sq Hill a try first.

nToiFSVaM2pjfeQoT2u9pg.text: If my friend hadn't suggested we meet here for dinner, I don't think I would have stopped in at Bangkok Balcony due to the dark exterior but I'm glad that I experienced this spot. We were seated near the black tinted window and the lighting made it all feel cozy but a little like we were warped back in time. Also the silverware I was not a fan of (they look like fiddlesticks which are ugly to me!). Anyway...  I couldn't decide between the yellow and mussaman curry so I asked the waitress. She said the yellow curry was good but on the sweet side and then her eyes totally lit up when she spoke about the mussaman curry, which was more of an Indian curry and of thicker consistency. I was sold on her description for mussaman and another friend actually changed her mind to order this too. By how excited our waitress was for us, we knew we were in for a treat.  Out came a pot of the mussaman curry and a bowl of rice. While the volume looks small, the contents are quite filling. The curry was absolutely delicious (I had a spice level of 5), not too sweet with a peanut coconut curry taste in potatoes and chicken. The potatoes were soft but the chicken was just the tiniest bit overcooked however once I smothered some of the curry sauce I ate it all up. Actually I ended up eating the whole thing up by putting the curry sauce on everything even though I was full!  Pleasant experience with the service and extremely satisfied with my dish that I will venture back.

5hqzh4HwMlPIG0G38Vw7lw.text: The server was misinformed or didn't care that I can't eat any animal products and told me the papaya salad was vegan and then came back after I had already eaten some to tell me that it did have fish sauce. I knew I felt weird. I had to go to the bathroom and force myself to throw up. If you are vegan, have allergies, etc. I would be very careful trusting the servers to know what is ok for you to eat. The fresh rolls were very good, but I'm not sure if I should trust that the curry is vegan despite her saying numerous times it is ok for me...she said the same about the salad. There are Thai places around Pittsburgh that are certified vegan friendly by Vegan Pittsburgh and clearly this is not one of those places.

2BdsGzWvM-3OP9T5dxTPrg.text: First timer.  But very good pad thai and salad. Ate there with a BB veteran who highly recommended it.  I walked past the restaurant twice before I found it - but very happy that I did!  Large portions - but skip the silverware and eat with the chopsticks.  They are easier to use than the silverware (which is very thin and slippery).  Got the spice level "5" and thought that it was spot on for what I had expected.  Looking forward to going back and upping the ante to an "8"!

06-WFvTDg4g3qcr_RYt40g.text: The Pad See Ew here was quite good; however, I am not convinced the Chicken Satay we ordered was cooked enough.  I did not get sick, but I also did not continue to eat it after I had concern.  The service was above average, and wine very reasonably priced.  I would definitely return but not order anything with meat.

uDiw_wKXfa9wrQ8F7KK6ww.text: I love Thai food and have tried almost every single Thai restaurant in Pittsburgh. Bangkok Balcony was pretty good, but a little expensive for the food. The ambience is really nice- great date night spot. However, Nicky's Thai Kitchen or Smiling Banana Leaf are better and cheaper.

H1q_WFwigWO4Nc0Dx9l6Tw.text: Not only was the food excellently prepared, but wait staff were polite. Quick service, nice wine selection.

MFz8Jv1bDIg8nNE8o3uBeg.text: The upstairs location makes this gem a little hard to notice from the street, but once inside you'll be glad you noticed this gem.  The heat level of all dishes marked spicy are made to order on a 1 to 10 heat scale.  My wife and I had lunch here, the meal consisted of:  Me Kraab - A little greasy but delicious! Ask for extra cilantro with it, balances out the dish very well. Three Flavor Fish - A sea bass, fried and covered in a spicy sauce. Not too greasy, the sauce was very flavorful, not just heat. (We got it at a 7.5/10 heat) Red Curry - A red curry dish, we got it with beef. The curry was very good, I would highly recommend the dish overall, but the beef was underwhelming - get it with shrimp or chicken. (Also at a 7.5/10)

TuuiSX-7oPDJyqQPeHJMPA.text: We went on a Sunday  afternoon and were seated by the big windows right away. My fiance asked the server for "really spicy," he laughed, and made sure when he brought the dish out that it was spicy enough. We got lamb curry and it was DELICIOUS! Will definitely return. A bit pricey, but so is most Thai food in the burgh.

uNgKvkyYeYKn_JmarXx3pw.text: My favorite Thai food in Pittsburgh. However they have downsized their portions a lot over the last year and they charge for extra rice (after they shrunk the portions).  Best flavor around but the value of the meal has taken a huge step back.

94wt2Oc3Ez9M4gpKhkMnng.text: Hands down the best thai in the United States. I've been fortunate enough to travel throughout the U.S. and I always order curry and brown rice. The pineapple curry at Bangkok Balcony is #1.

-C_ngGfP_pmUm8J4hPPaHQ.text: Pineapple fried rice is awesome. The ambience is so good, that you can bring your date or cool off with your buddy and grab a beer. The staff is amazing polite and really quick to service. Love the place where you can seat right near the window area. Overall it was satisfying experience and will like to go again and try something new.

uB2uwtELQnn3OXD7kWAI7Q.text: COLD/WARM EXPENSIVE/WEAK  The above four words pretty much express how we felt after our dinner experience on Thursday evening, June 2, 2016.  First the cold:  {and expensive}  Ordered the Thai spring roll--deep fried and cut at an angle in half--perhaps to hide their small size at $3.95 for two.  When their cut before serving they tend to cool a little faster. Ordered the Praram Chicken ($16.95) over spinach and smothered in some kind of peanut sauce.  This dish arrive luke warm-cold and the serving looked like a lunch portion.  It was tasty but not much there and I could have made this dish at home.  They didn't sautee the spinach but put a thin layer of raw spinach under the chicken.  My dinner partner ordered the chicken satay ($7.95) for five.  He said it was ok but had better elsewhere.  He also had the chili paste chicken ($14.95) with more green beans than chicken.  Again middle of the road where you could have ordered the same thing at one of those asian restaurants with pictures on the walls and more chicken and at a cheaper rate.  Weak:  We both had Jasmine Tea which arrived in a cup with hot water and a tea bag--very weak tea and required at least two tea bags each per cup to make it strong enough to taste.  Asked the waitress if there were free refills and she said "Yes, I can bring you more hot water."  I thought I misunderstood her and when we ordered more tea she said she would bring the hot water.  I explained the tea was very weak when she said you only get one tea bag of FOOJOY tea [$9.99 per 100] per person.  She finally gave in and brought us a small teapot of hot water with tea bags.  Does this restaurant need to nickel and dime guests over cheap/weak tea bags?  Warm:  Ever heard of AIR CONDITIONING Bangkok Balcony?  It was warm and humid that evening and there wasn't evening air circulating from any vents.  Maybe they are trying to keep their electric bill low.  I don't know about you, but I like to dine in a comfortable climate controlled environment especially at these prices.  Total bill $52.22 for two!!!

xC4GhpC4T4nUa3PbOxTA3w.text: Every dish is substitutable to be vegetarian, which is awesome! Good atmosphere, love the climb up the stairs to a relatively intimate and cozy dining area. Servers are nice, and there are always people walking around to fill up your water.  Not my favorite Thai food in Pittsburgh, but definitely one of the top 5. Hope to see this place stay in business for a long time!

SDwpBHAe6cpnVBfilW45Ow.text: Horrible experience!  So disappointing.  How do you mess up hot tea -- forget to heat the water -- never less -- Bangkok Balcony couldn't even get the hot tea right.  My husband order a 10 spice level and I ordered a 5.  There was ZERO spice added and mild was below what we were served.  The service was sooo slow, too.  Don't waste your money.  Pick another Thai place to try.  Oh, and the chef needs to return to cooking school.

oWA6GW5T5V8w8IOIPDpo_g.text: This place is so inconsistent I cannot stand it. They're lemongrass soup is solid - just get it not spicy and spice it yourself.  When it comes to the stir fried stuff, it gets complicated.  You spice it yourself, it doesn't get mixed evenly.  You tell the 6/10 one day and they give you a 8/10.  You tell them 4/10 on another day they give you a 8/10.  Never again because they obviously don't give a hoot about your tolerance.  This place is also expensive, considering that they apparently don't really operate on a spice scale and also, very little meat.  It's all filler.  I would give it three, but I grade on curve (Thai cuisine curve) and this one is definitely below average.

_FyaxW2v9ayEfyVBwKvttw.text: I've dined at Bangkok Balcony a few times. A couple of times, I've ordered one of the stir-fry dishes. The dishes are good but cost a nickel under $14 which is a bit expensive for a stir-fry dish. On my most memorable visit, I ordered a daily special which was served as a whole fish over rice with a Thai chili sauce. The presentation of the dish was rather surprising as they served an entire fish (head and all) as opposed to a fillet which caught me off guard.  One of the convenient aspects of the restaurant is that you can rate how spicy you would like the dish on a scale of 1 to 10.  There is also window seating available where you can overlook Forbes Ave while having dinner.  All in all, Bangkok Balcony is a nice and intimate restaurant but a bit expensive for the type of food they are serving.

9Kipbcu5-ZLmSp7S0U356Q.text: The staff that works there is extremely charming and helpful. The food was good but nothing out of the ordinary (although the coconut soup was exceptional). What would have made the Massaman exceptional was the size of the chicken and potatoes. Because the chicken pieces were so large it was on the dry side. I think if it had been smaller it would have incorporated with the tasty sauce more.

ymZEp9PH6twJWsl1O6qefw.text: Years ago I routinely went to Bangkok Balcony for lunch.  Food was delicious and well priced.   Unfortunately, If my meal today is any indicator,  Bangkok Balcony has gone to the dogs.  My luncheon special of noodles and pork with egg and some other things was more than disappointing.  From 1 to 10 (ten being the hottest) I asked for 7.   Now that's pretty hot, right? Well,  the meal not only wasn't hot,  it had no taste.    The egg roll appetizer had been CRISPED to death.   It too had no flavor.   The soup was passable; it tasted just like Swanson's canned chicken broth. (I sent my meal back and we were not charged.)    I hate to see a formerly nice restaurant decline like this.  Hopefully the chef will right the situation and return Bangkok Balcony to its former glory.

2icEAqg5K6lXWCUBGaF5WQ.text: Nice decor. The restaurant is overpriced, at 8 bucks for some standard appetizers and many of the main entrees are ~30"% pricier than typical Pittsburgh Thai cuisine  not enough savoring during this visit to come back soon...

YhSWEogsbYNgDCqsly4zaA.text: We came in with a group of 10 with no reservation on a Saturday night, and they were able to seat us.  We started with the lettuce wraps and the fried eggplant appetizer. The eggplant definitely stood out between the two.  I ordered the panang curry and it had great flavor, wasn't too spicy (I went with a 2 out of 10), I loved the little corn in it, and I had leftovers to take home. This is definitely a great place to share plates.

PbXX1hMKmkEtZM_P5S5fXg.text: Really really average I frequently visit Thai and Asian restaurants in Pittsburgh and was excited to try something new. I picked up my order and took it home only to realize my order had been made with beef and not chicken. The noodles were soggy and bland. The price was steep for such an average tasting meal. We ordered the see ew noodles and the chili paste beef. It wasn't terrible and the location is good. Over priced for what you get compared to the other restaurants in Pittsburgh

EpzT7a3BwjeA2S7uWTc-2A.text: I was sad to be disappointed with the food, especially after all the rave reviews. We tried the lemongrass soup, shrimp in garlic sauce, lemongrass noodles and something from the specials menu. The lemongrass soup was cold - but our server was great and warmed it up for me. The food was nothing special. 5 stars for the service. 1 for the food.

Fz5sOianbfihXgT35Lo6FQ.text: "I...don't...know...what the hell that was, but I'm not eating it." That was my reaction to the steamed dumplings at Bangkok Balcony last night. I spit the dumpling out, and threw the rest away. They tasted like an old mildewy dishrag or something. One of the foulest things I've ever tasted. Seriously.  It was our first experience with Bangkok Balcony. We got takeout, and my first impressions of the place were good. The hostess was nice, and the bartender who gave me my food was also really nice. It looked like a great atmosphere for dinner, as well, so I left the restaurant excited to try their food and already thinking about coming back to dine in.  Then I had to ruin it by eating the food:(  Perhaps we should've gone with one of their curries that had good reviews on here, but I just wanted something simple last night. I got pad thai, and It was okay, but definitely not worth going back for, and I didn't even finish it (a rarity for me, as I usually finish my meal AND whatever meal my wife orders).  We also ordered the fresh spring rolls and dumplings. I already discussed the disaster that was the dumpling order, and while the spring rolls were okay, I'm not sure I'd order them again IF I ever go back. They were poorly rolled and the tofu inside was so ridiculously big that all you could taste...was tofu. One positive was that their brown dipping sauce was good enough to get you through any bland spring roll you could ever encounter.  Overall, it's going to be a tough pull to get me to go back. I'd hate to hinge that decision on something as simple as pad thai, dumplings, and fresh spring rolls when their curries get such good reviews. Unfortunately, I wasn't in the mood for a curry last night, and just wanted a basic first taste of Bangkok Balcony...and that first taste was thoroughly disappointing.

gWUcRkpSLnbvc6EzfBLaQQ.text: I love this place. Sometimes the pad thai is hit or miss though, hence why only 4 stars.  I love the lunch specials: soup, salad, egg roll, and dish for $8.25? Perfect deal. Soup is wonderful, as is the egg roll! I don't eat salad but I'm sure it's great too!

uvrxw9eJsuhW4SydfZad3w.text: We've been coming to Bangkok Balcony for years. Food is reliably good. Lemongrass noodles and garlic chicken are our go to meals. Today had pumpkin soup and Thai spring roles that were very good. Highly recommend the place.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pumpkin soup and Thai spring rolls

B8AsDkC1wmy-njfIF-NWCg.text: This is, by far, my favorite Thai restaurant. We order from here often, and I always get the pumpkin chicken curry. My only complaint is that with this particular curry, the chicken comes in larger pieces and is sometimes dry/overcooked. When we ordered this past week, however, the chicken was perfect.   My fiance loves their pineapple chicken curry, and with his the chicken is sliced thinly so he doesn't ever run into this problem. His only complaint is that I order it too much!   For the few times we have gone in to eat, the service has been very friendly!

rlXqmdy0z4WDYIRy4Re7Tg.text: Good but slow service. My 4 year old tried the chicken satay for the first time and liked it!  My son wanted curry so we got the massaman chicken curry. The pad thai was okay. Overall a good experience.

CXfDGcqQIp7RBsDD06yPLQ.text: One of my favorite Thai places. I usually get the green curry with chicken with a number 8 spice level. Hot, but not unbearable.  Thai basil leaf chicken is what I like to call Thai halushki. Sauteed cabbage, basil leaf, chicken and it's delish! I've had the other curry choices and all are good. Pumpkin soup was very smooth and a good starter.

wL90RQputQRtKELDV5wc7w.text: Basically, this place is terrible. I ate here last night. Given the location, number of positive reviews, and number of diners I always see there, I expected, at a minimum, a decent meal. However, I was sorely disappointed. First of all, this place is way overpriced: $14 for panang curry (of a minuscule portion size) and $4 for two measly spring rolls. Also, there was a $2.25 extra charge for getting brown instead of white rice. (Yikes!) This is Pittsburgh for god's sake. Secondly, the quality of the food was laughable. The curry was watery, the vegetables were sparse, and the tofu was rubbery and tasted like old gym socks.   On the plus side, the service was good. But, all things considered, I would definitely recommend that you pass on this place.

wr5AYEhx4AGl3gGzZCcucQ.text: One of my favourite restaurants in Pittsburgh.  Authentic Thai dishes, great decor and really good service.  The spicy lime salad dressing is mouth watering good!

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken curry.
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Welcome

DqC94iv0OaPloOaDaVchzA.text: I know that a lot of people like BB, but I have to be honest here and speak from experience.  This was NOT A GOOD EXPERIENCE AT ALL!  Especially after having such great eats at places like Nicky's Thai Kitchen and the Smiling Banana Leaf.    Pad thai... dry and no flavor.  WE figured they would have gotten one of our orders right and at least one of them would have been tasty... well that was not the case.   Their steamed dumplings were dry, inedible and just downright nasty.... one bite and we tossed them away.    The only redeeming part of the meal was the fresh spring rolls which were at best, decent.    I won't be going back here after our experience.  Like I said, with better Thai options in town, it makes sense to continue to go there at this point as they have always been good and never failed us.

tKLuvuYn_PX5eNdBbvuIGg.text: My boyfriend and I went last Friday night.  The service was good; we were seated right away and the wait staff was attentive.  However, the food was sub-par and expensive!  I've had much better thai for much less money at smiling banana leaf, thai me up or nicky's.  Try one of those instead.

BapxKITJOlVgsn9kL_eOLQ.text: Everything here is overpriced thai food and similar tasting, but I would sacrifice my firstborn child for the pumpkin curry at bangkok balcony. I'm not ashamed to say I keep a pumpkin curry fund in my budget just so I can shovel $18 per pumpkin curry(curry, tax, and tip) to feed my crack-like addiction.   Pumpkin has a texture that's better than sweet potato, potato, carrots, or taro for a perfect marriage with thai curry that will never ever end in divorce. If that EVER happens, I will be one VERY unhappy child.  One negative is the silverware. The head of the forks and spoons in my hand outweight the mass of the food, leaving me unsatisfied.  PUMPKIN CURRY!!

7fkE2AxD5ZxFr3BJC8oVuQ.text: Two words: Thai Samosas.   Puffy crispy sweet potato triangles with a sublime sticky honey dipping sauce. Words can't describe how yummy they are. Okay, my words can't.  Very nice location, loved to sit by the window overlooking Forbes. Squi Hi, as I called it, is tre adorable.    The entrees are decent. But sometimes the pad thai was hearty as hell, sometimes I was like "where are all the noodles?"   I had really terrible service here once. I don't blame the restaurant, just the one guy who had no business being in the service industry. He refused to bring me a side of spring roll sauce (I wanted it to spruce up some some bland entree) because "that dish doesn't come with that sauce". Even though I had already eaten an order of spring rolls! What a freak.   Overall, another great Pittsburgh/Squirrel Hill asset.

d5WJnvpBBxv6s_whBqBy5g.text: I went back to Pittsburgh recently and went out of my way to come here (again)! Even during the high Friday night crowd, they were able to seat a group of 6 within 5 minutes. Of course, I had a coconut martini, which was as delicious as I remembered! I tried the pumpkin curry with tofu; it was AMAZING! The pumpkin and tofu were perfectly cooked!   Hats off to you, Bangkok Balcony!

rmSKIaUOoTuBcfu6x47wfw.text: The seating is great, it's a very nice place for a date.  I had lunch there and could easily imagine being on a very nice date there.  My food was pretty good.  I wouldn't go on a limb and say it was outstanding.  It was good, and it wasn't too expensive.  The waitstaff was helpful and sweet.

JAHXgzpHeHCatr6IYIycIw.text: I remember when Bangkok Balcony still opened. I was a college student at CMU, right down Forbes Avenue. Lemongrass used to be in that location, and it was pretty good. So, I was wondering what the new place would bring. Well, at that point I was pleasantly surprised by the renovated restaurant still making good use of the 2nd floor windows overlooking Forbes Avenue. The food was tasty and, coupled with the fact that it was close by, I remember coming here all the time. Someone's birthday? Bangkok Balcony! Stress Relief from Finals? Bangkok Balcony! Hungry and Procrastinating? Bangkok Balcony!   I went back for the first time in many years this past week and was let down. The food just wasn't what I remembered it to be. It's still okay, and for someone who doesn't walk in with high expectations, it probably will do. I had a very safe dish - the Penang Curry, which was decent but there are better ones in Pittsburgh (Thai Cuisine in Liberty, for one). The rice wasn't really that good either - and really, how do you f*&k up rice? Two of my dining friends had the Pad See Ew, which they really didn't like. One of them said "it tastes sour, like vinegar." While I'm no expert about what ingredients should go into Pad See Ew, the look on her disappointed face told me the vinegar taste was not appreciated.   Overall I would give it 3 stars because I think a lot of the experience was tainted by high expectations. Even tho I still like the location and feel of the restaurant, I don't think I'll be going back because I just don't want to waste a good meal. I can enjoy myself much more with the Pad Thai from Spice Island, or the curry from Thai Cuisine.   Oh - and yes I admit that I have f*%&ed up rice before, but I don't cook and make other people pay to eat it. Restaurants don't have the same leeway!

-9hA4YGRb_HFbdy3O5O8Fg.text: I was more impressed with Squirrel Hill itself than I was with Bangkok Balcony. My friend and I found this place on a "vegan's guide to Pittsburgh" type Web site, and they were open late, so that worked for us. We found street parking very easily. I was disappointed that most of the clothing stores were closed, because there was such a great mix of vintage and new fashions.   I digress. I really liked the layout of BB... how it's on the top floor and everything is modern without being sterile. We both really liked the flatware they use here, and that's something we almost never comment on. They had a good selection of tofu items and I loved how they asked me to tell them how spicy I wanted my food "on a scale from one to ten." The food here is also more inexpensive than I would have thought, seeing how packed the place was and how nicely decorated.   Overall, it was good, but I'm biased -- I love Thai food so much that I could eat it all the time. The reason I'm only giving this place three stars is because we both felt a little sick later on in the evening.

JqUbVHl2jgxarvvxjI2edw.text: This place has grown on me. I think their spicy scale is on the mild side....   Waitress: "How hot, on a scale of 1-10 would you like your dish?" Me: "What do you usually get?" Waitress: "A 10..." Me: "Ok, give me a 10."  I think my glass was still half full by the time I had finished most of my dish. I think their 10 was more like a 7 or 8. But who knows, maybe that just says something about me? :o)  Food is pretty tasty, the staff is friendly, and I really like sitting by the window-wall. I think the only way inside is to hike up the stairs, so keep that in mind for the stair-phobic.

XkoGyKu2NkdHytDX_Lramg.text: good food - a bit more pricey than other options.  Nothing stands out about Bangkok Balcony, but the food is consistent, decent portion size, and a bar is available (which can be a rarity at a lot of Thai restaurants).

trzcxuCVKrosD06dFSL8yg.text: Very good Thai food.  Tasty without being too overwhelming.  The spicy level (1-10) is right on where it should be.  We had chicken labb salad which was tasty and spicy as we like.  I do wish the labb salad come with sticky rice as it is usually served in Thailand though.  Grilled pork with sticky rice was flavorful which tell me the pork has been properly tenderize and marinated.  Overall, this is a great place to visit if you are in the mood for Thai (or Asian) food in the area.

YenrperVnuNvm-hGgorgIQ.text: It's really good food and service was good also. However it is slightly overpriced.

w0VE1ePd5pR4fquW0F14dA.text: I grew up with this great Thai place near where I went to high school - it was cheap, fresh, and cheap. It's still the best Pad Thai I've ever had.  So I must explain this is why I only give Bangkok Balcony 4 stars. Bangkok Balcony is still great, it is flavorful and tasty, and I've never had a bad meal there. It's just not quite as fresh as the Thai I grew up with.   I recommend their curries - the sauces are very tasty and savory. The staff is very attentive and it's always a good time.

9341zNnO3a1Fna5YwHk71A.text: The Balcony is probably my favorite Thai place in the Pittsburgh area: their menu is varied, their service is consistently stellar, and their food has never let me down.  On top of all of this, the Balcony sits mightily atop Norka Futon, meaning there are four "tables for two" that give diners a nice view of Forbes avenue below them, meaning you can enjoy your food with a nice dose of people-watching.  For the year I lived in Squirrel Hill, the Balcony was one of my main eating locales (especially since they're open a little later than most Pittsburgh restaurants tend to stay open), and even after moving away from there, I still eat at the Balcony with some regularity.  Although the Balcony has been around for a while and has undergone multiple owners now (and several different variations in menu design), their food has remained pretty much the same - which is a good thing!  Their core curries and Thai noodle/rice dishes are presented well and taste flavorful without being overwhelmingly greasy.  Their more exotic fare, although sometimes less filling, are often presented even more nicely and taste just as good.  All of the food is brought on oval plates with serving utensils, which sit on your table in addition to everyones' own dinner plates, encouraging sharing of dishes among the party.  Their drinks (Thai Ice Tea and Coffee, and various juices including mango) are a nice treat for fans of Thai beverages.  With reasonable prices and a short walk down the stairs to walk off the meal afterwards, there's not much more one can ask for.

N7odXffiybEn7SXuFqXR1g.text: Great Thai place.  I go here often and will continue.  If you like Thai and are in Squirrel Hill be sure to go.

E0cJYgxRsChFIAe715YHCg.text: Love this place!! Great atmosphere, service, food and beer selection! Love pairing one of their fantastic curries with an Anchor Porter. And don't forget to get spring rolls to start out! My favorites are Panang Curry or Red Curry with Beef...spice level 7.  If you aren't a curry fan try the Basil Leaf w/Beef.

ksOc0TNVfj9PxyRUKPuUog.text: The spicy basil noodles with chicken are delicious. The pad thai is also very good- not as good as the recipe from Pim or Cooks Illustrated that I make at home, but best I've found in the PGH area. The springrolls are addicting, as is the chicken satay with the delicious peanut sauce and sweet cucumber sauce. The Beef Salad leaves much to be desired. Too much salt and fish sauce, not enough lime or lemongrass or cilantro. The calamari is bad, and horribly overpriced. The mussaman curry is delicious- but I hate that they cheap out and give you mostly potatoes and almost no chicken.  Overall, the food is very good...unfortunately it's overpriced and sometimes I feel like the owner is gouging his customers on dishes.

CZ7d5g8l0VLoEKMqF3KAvA.text: Bangkok Balcony is a nice spot, but it isn't the best Thai in town.  The tables are a little cramped, but if you're by the window you can enjoy the view of Forbes Ave.  The price is decent, but I don't think I've been able to get in and out in a decent amount of time.  Between waiting for a table and the slow orders expect to be there a while.

0O-CLcx8TnrXk7Brb7pQVA.text: Decent food, nice space and attentive service.   Two in my party ordered the duck curry and both seemed to enjoy it.  Another ordered pad thai, and I had the pineapple curry.  Mine was tasty, but not at all spicy, even though I requested a 7/10 spiciness. We all ordered tom yum soup, and I found it to be not nearly as good as I am used to eating elsewhere.  I also thought the rice to curry ratio was lacking and that the food was a bit overpriced.    Our waitress was very efficient.  My water glass was always full, and it did not take long to receive our meal, have leftovers wrapped, or to settle the bill.   The space is pretty large, and they have some pretty cool lights on the ceiling.  The bathroom was clean.    I would come back here for Thai food if in the area, but I would stress that I want to feel the heat and would not order the soup again.

7mMBMQZKCt6h3fRWhUzVzw.text: This is by far my favorite Thai Place to dine in. My favorite dish is the Panang Curry with chicken. Great eating environment.

pLhEnsty1a1skZcfrWnqhA.text: Beautiful atmosphere but way too pricey! They're skimpy on providing rice and tend to hold back on flavoring their entrees. Spiciness doesn't make bland food into good food.

duI_Z1BXR_OZohM9hXL_sw.text: Hard to find, impossible to leave.   I've been up and down this street plenty of times. Got sweets at Gaby et Jules, went shopping at Littles Shoes, but never seen this sign.   A friend recommended this place and I quickly hopped in the car at the prospect of getting some "Thai Food." I got the Green Curry and it was awesome. My friend group agrees, the spicy-ness scale is a little mild. I got a 5/10 and it wasn't at all hot, which was only disappointing for a second.   Plenty of great apps to choose from: old stand-bys like crab Rangoon and miso soup and some pretty elaborate lettuce wraps. Large selection of features for the more adventurous while maintaining a wide array of the dishes you come to expect like Pad Thai, See Ew, Curry, etc.   It's like 13.95 a dish, but if you're a petite eater it's two meals. If you eat like I do it's one glorious chow down that is well worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The inside decor is super clean and classy.

IEKAVmxX3Ety-7NnAabIFA.text: The BEST pumpkin curry I have ever had. Not to mention the best in Pittsburgh, and I have eaten it in many different restaurants.   Wish I could have packed up this establishment and moved it to Florida with me.

2m11LSO7gnV8XnGdFd9N1w.text: Very authentic Thai food. It sits on the second floor and has a good view if you take the window seats. I love their pad Thai and yellow curry dishes. They offer lunch special, which is a cheaper option than dinner. Hope they add more varieties.

GGfrC3yfHyEYx1AKQKiayw.text: Whenever I go to Bangkok Balcony I am usually with a huge group of friends. This last time there was 13 of us. They have always welcomed large parties and have been happy to separate our checks. Their drinks are on point. We had a round while deciding what we were going to have. Everyone on our side of the table went for Pad Thai. Their Pad Thai is one of my top 3 in the Burgh. I'm a wimp when it comes to spice yet they nail my spice level every time. The portion is huge. I think it was the first time I conquered the whole dish. I hadn't eaten that day and I was starving. The other side of our table leaned toward a range of curry lovers. It got so quiet when our food came. We dove right in. Eventually people started asking if others wanted to try their dishes. Sometimes you don't want to share. This is one of those times. However you do want people to see what you are living so much. It's the crunch of the peanuts with the softness of the noodles, with the zing of the lime, and that small tang of cilantro. It's a great bite.  Their staff is very friendly and the service is great.

yPKo_DM6lf5BfpGf8wXKBg.text: Came here on a Saturday night, shortly before it closed at 11 PM. It wasn't busy so we walked in and were seated immediately. Service was pleasant and very fast; we were able to order within the first 10-12 minutes of taking our seats.   The menu had a good number of options. I don't eat much Thai food, so the descriptions made it easy for me to decide what I might like. I ended up choosing not to venture out and just ordered the Beef Pad Thai. It was really good! My only disappointment was that I ordered it spicy level 8 and it wasn't spicy at all... My friend ordered the Chicken Thai Style Rice, and it was also really good!   Overall, prices were reasonable. Service was quick and all the employees were helpful and polite. The atmosphere was relaxing. The view over Forbes Ave. was cool though it wasn't anything special. I'd definitely recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Thai and Thai Style Rice

to4Jn-fFNz3KcO7_G39AqA.text: Green curry tofu and pad Thai tofu are my favorite. Lunch specials are great with the soup and spring rolls. Got it delivered for the first time. Good time.

1VO1sgUT4aq8fwxeLwS2FQ.text: Bankok Balcony never disappoints me. Been there a couple of times, and it's lived up to my satisfaction. We frequently visit Silk Elephant too, I cannot see much of a difference taste-wise between the 2 restaurants, especially when you compare their curries. My favorites are the red curry, the pad thai, the thai fried rice. Recently we tried the fried fish in chilli sauce, it was a bit pricy (18$) but the fish was very nicely cooked and tender&delicious to taste. I am also a fan of their thai iced teas. I like the seating area, the ambience is trendy as well as casual. Overall, a really good Thai restaurant in Squirrel Hill.

A0V0OAtbz6uBIOxVwJEHKw.text: Used the Yelp app to order take out online.  easy to use and the restaurant got it all right. There was a question about the order and I quickly got a call from Bangkok to clarify. The green curry was perfectly spiced and the shrimp and mixed veggies was mild for the husband. I love the Fresh Spring roll and Thai rolls too. Lots of leftovers that were enjoyed for the next few days.

rupdczTB6X0U1t-A7DnP4A.text: ONE OF THE MOST DISAPPOINTING DINNERS I'VE EVER HAD.  I had eaten here a few years ago and remembered it fondly. But last night was more than disappointing - it was painful.  First we waited in our seats 15 minutes before being helped.  The food was also bad (I can't even say mediocre). My dish was cold and the meat that was supposed to be beef was not identifiable as any type of meat.  The beans were barely cooked not al dente but almost raw.  After we finished our meal, we waited another 15 minutes to get our check. Actually we never got our check .  But when we started walking toward the door they gave it to me.  (I have never done it, but I almost would have walked out without paying.)  Try the other great Thai places in Squirrel Hill unless they get their act together again.

kkmyTuDFeXpCQKgT2T8rVg.text: Have not been in this place in 20 years,  came back to visit Pitt, and sister loves this place, WOW pretty good stuff. Had the Curry Peanut chicken on bed of spinach, loads of flavor, nice portion, and well packed togo containers. ordered the steamed dumpliings, these were above average, not enough dipping sauce (they could have filled the 2 ounce container all the way up... got about an ounce of sauce) interesting pineapple fried rice w/chicken...cashews a nice taste, but should have used fresh pineapple for the price. sister oredred garlic chicken, smelled much better than it tasted, light on flavor. Sauce could have been a little thicker. service was quick and organized for takeout at 5pm on a cooollllldddd  monday night. will Truely eat there again, i'll try eat in next time 5 spice is not very spicy. But sister says spice is not consistent.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Curry peanut on spinach
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Steamed dumplings. More sauce please

ECU7g0qQmGwVneZLyqVXWQ.text: My friends and I were actually trying to go to another restaurant down the street for lupper (lunch/supper), but it was closed. I'm so glad, because Bangkok Balcony is great!  What I really like is the ambiance. It feels classy and authentic, with red and gold accents all around, Thai paintings... We got a great table near the windows overlooking the street. The service was also really good.  The food was ok. I got the shrimp pad thai, which is kind of what I get at every Thai restaurant. It tasted pretty typical. Maybe a little pricey for what the food is like, but it seemed like they had a better lunch deal that we missed. I'd totally go back to check out their lunch.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. The shrimp pad thai

1BhNBR6U-AetPzDMqvFQrg.text: I ordered th Duck Curry - while the flavors were fantastic, I found that for the amount I had paid I wished there was more to it. It was heavy on the pineapple, but fairly light on everything else. It did comes with a good dose of steamed white rice on the side though! And the Thai iced tea was really creamy and delicious.

T6R1z7N5-oL2A3JJgX1CiQ.text: Worst Thai food I've ever had. Ordered Thai fried rice with chicken. The chicken was under cooked and the rice tasted worse than boxed bland brown rice.

ejXXPS27nuRA5ObyoLu49w.text: Seafood is not worth the price. The lemongrass soup is not a typical Thailand one,I felt a little disappointed.

IbJCxS7scjPe9fidzwD-JQ.text: First time at this place for a GNO and I like the food here a lot. I heard some negative reviews about this place from my friends but I actually thought it wasn't that bad  Ordered chicken yellow curry, pineapple chicken fried rice, vegetable pad thai and a several other dishes and they were all yummy. Do agree with some reviewers that the chicken in curry was very big and chunky. But other than that everything was great

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Delicious

UqLg0i6YJASI2QCZjq-uhg.text: Just your average thai food. Decently priced considering the quality. You can adjust the spiciness for your order, but know that it tends to be on the lower side to cater to the American customer base (order a higher level of spiciness to compensate for the adjusted scale). Portions are adequate, but the service is fairly slow.

68T2pZ6N0vgCPC9ZLgu4Wg.text: Been eating at Bangkok Balcony for over a decade, and it's always been great! Their food's every bit as tasty as what I've eaten in Chiang Mai, Krabi, and--of course--Bangkok. Decor is rich but not overwhelming, and makes for a pleasant dining environment.

p2t5RaHes4HVCJZI71sXjA.text: Consistently good-tasting food, with the best tofu eggplant in the neighborhood (my favorite dish). I also love their green curry. I tend to only come here for the lunch special, which is very well-priced, perfectly proportioned, and has tofu eggplant as an option! Their Pad Thai is not my favorite in town but it is also good. They also have beer and wine, I think, though I tend not to indulge at lunch.

uOl3ukN3XROYIPLnuGXaIA.text: Cool in my book!  The service, atmosphere, and foods are very good. The staff was very friendly, accommodating, and knowledgeable in regard to the menu.  I had the chicken satays and the vegetable pad thai. The chicken satays were good and came with peanut sauce for dipping. The vegetable pad thai was great, and you can choose your hot/spicy level.   I will definitely be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Veggie Pad Thai to go
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Vegetable Pad Thai
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Chicken Satay

suD4ZXOG2qj1bG8mZn5V-A.text: So my friend loves this place and claims that it has one of the best curries in Pittsburgh.  He recommended for me the pumpkin chicken curry while he got the yellow chicken curry. The wait wasn't long at all, because the table we got was right by the window and we passed our time by people watching.  At first I was disappointed by the portions but I was pleasantly surprised by how filling the meal was. The chicken was a little dry probably due to the over sized chunks that were stewed in the curry. However, the curry was perfectly creamy and flecked with chili flakes to satisfy my love of spice.

7XncR4-rA7YwzIjNy2hIkg.text: I love stopping here from time to time and getting the yellow curry with tofu.  My daughter loves it too. The dishes are big and if you get an extra rice you can both share but I just order 2 curries and take the rest home for lunch/ dinner another day!  My husband gets the broccoli, and he loved this one especially with chicken but says he can eat more. Service has always been great for me every time I've come. I've been coming here for years -shana

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

J5Zy9VTzPhyqX9yrfqmTYw.text: We typically don't go to Squirrel Hill too often and although we've tried many Thai restaurants in various other locations around the city, this was our first trip to Bangkok Balcony. We stopped in for lunch and only 1 other couple was in the restaurant.   Service was great - very attentive and timely. We ordered the lunch specials , garlic pork for me and ginger pork for my husband.   The starter was pretty good - in the 3 star range - tofu soup, lettuce salad with peanut dressing & a spring roll with dipping sauce. Then the meals arrived. In spite of the beautiful veggies and tender pork on both dishes, they had no flavor. We had ordered spice levels of 6 & 7 and there was zero spice in either dish.   I expect a good Thai dish to wake up my taste buds with all the vibrant spices and sauces. These dishes put our taste buds to sleep.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Garlic Pork
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lunch Starter - Tofu Soup, Spring Roll &amp; Salad

gkbJIxLEA9-VhLJA0bTjbw.text: I love Thai food and have made it a personal quest to try every single Thai restaurant in and around the city. I'm nearly finished with that adventure and despite wanting to get to Bangkok Balcony for years, I hadn't made it till today. I consider myself a near expert on Thai food (big shout out to northside Nicky's for years of showing me how it's done) and I can say without question that I'd be hard pressed to come up with a place that Bangkok Balcony is better than. Now, not that it was awful, it just was completely bland, without flavor, and with pork that was just a touch chewy. In fact, if I had never had Thai food before and this was my first exposure to it, I'd never eat it again.   The ginger pork was like eating soggy cardboard. I always like spicy Thai. This had no spice and no flavor. The salad, soup, and spring roll apps were ok. But the main entree? No thanks.   There are FAR better places to get your Thai cravings satisfied. I'd go to any of those before I'd come here.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Maybe it&#39;s me but the utensils really bugged me!! The curl on the end made the fork want to keep rolling over in your hand.
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Ginger pork. Looks better than it tasted n

alEdsam_ByuPub8ngRa50w.text: Pros:  -quick service -awesome window views -excellent seafood curry -tasty rice pudding for dessert   Cons: -slightly expensive for the portion sizes, I easily finished off my curry (with all the rice) and still had room for dessert.     I'd say this place is pretty comparable to Silk Elephant in the taste department, however Silk Elephant portion sizes mean that I can take my leftovers home and have lunch the next day.

1lLHbPxU8w357YPPJtf94g.text: I had seafood with Basil leaves. It was ok. But it just tasted like seafood + tomato sauce. I can cook that at home! And it is expensive. Not worth it. I had a small bite of my friend's noodles. It was more Thai than what I ordered. But still, you can have the same in other cheaper Thai restaurant.   But the environment is really nice. Ask for a seat near the window. It would be a really nice date setup.

biB5PA5cpG-DMR_Yhu_afg.text: Great restaurant!! Delicious Thai food, as good as any in the city.  Plus really friendly wait staff and great view of downtown Squirrel Hill.  Love their Spring Rolls, Tom Yum Soup.  Highly recommend!  Our family will be back for dinner tonight!!

hQOnn5K1DB4HO0100BWShQ.text: Well. Sorry to say this but you guys ruined our graduation dinner. It  was my first time and last one at your place. I was with my family and I asked to the bartender something and he went like Ask your server...  then the food took over 45 min to get on the table; when we six were the only ones in the restaurant at the time plus  a table of two behind us.  My father in low was no happy with his meal and he drove over 5 hours to eat in this place. On top, whenever the server came for the order I asked him to give me his best dish... he brought me Some fish dish.. I got two bites...  it was to blend.   But not done.... you guys included the tip on the bill! However and over what you charge us we decided to put some cash on the table.  To many mistakes in just one party! Sorry to say. No coming back.  It was April 29. 2018.

dpm-wyLuQ8KIvA-qnHp2LQ.text: Bangkok Balcony has the some of the best curries that I've had in Pittsburgh. They serve lunch specials which are very reasonably priced, and they come with multiple different items like salad, egg roll, soup, and entree. It's also really close to college campuses, which makes it the ideal spot for date nights. Would strongly recommend!

oTHIFrh1-6FAVt66IlqP3w.text: As far as Thai goes, it's probably not the best in the city, but definitely serviceable for a good delivery option. The food is tasty, but we were disappointed in the amount of protein for the price. We ordered the pumpkin and green curries. Pumpkin curry is one of my favorites - but there were just three pieces of chicken.  Otherwise I was happy with the meal.

_3SIWFo8T2qPtd70ZOQOTg.text: Good place in Squirrel Hill for delicious Thai food and a fun atmosphere. The dining room overlooks the road as it is on the second floor of the building. Reservations are accepted but it wasn't busy when we stopped on a Sunday night. Staff was very professional and polite. They had Thai dancers performing in the dining room which created a fun atmosphere but it was still intimate and not distracting to those having a quiet meal.   The portions were large and I had plenty f leftovers to take home. The shrimp and tofu red curry was perfectly spices for me at a 4 on a scale of 3-10. Red curry is my favorite and I always order it anytime I eat Thai food. While I thought it was good here, I do prefer it elsewhere where I have had it with more vegetables and pineapple which I find to be a perfect contrast to the spice. I would probably not get this again if I return. I also had the fresh spring rolls as an appetizer which had a nice presentation, but I found to be slightly dry.   Overall, I probably will go elsewhere if I find myself craving Thai cuisine, but if I am in the area, I wouldn't be opposed to eating here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Red curry with shrimp and tofu

IlB8pgld_S3l0Lttn9OfzQ.text: PSA: they have $5 glasses of wine! And there's several to choose from. And the Chardonnay isn't terrible.  Second PSA: the setting sun cuts into eye level - avoid the east wall around that time.  Ok now to dive into the rest of my experience: the service was on the slow side. I actually think they intended to bring our wine at the same time as our food, which I find a little weird. Either that or they forgot about the wine until I reminded them. Not sure.  I ordered the curry fried rice with tofu (my favorite thing to order at Thai restaurants). The fried rice was good except...there was tomato in it. I'm not going to pretend to be an expert on Thai food, maybe tomato is a normal thing to put in fried rice, but I really did not like it. Something about hot tomato just didn't mesh with the rest of the dish.  They have a lot of things on their menu, and I'm happy about the wine. I'll probably come again in the future!

PX3HB1hs2bsRIrq0gJXLJA.text: Last min craving for Thai food. Only place that was open till 11pm on Sat.  Everything closed 10pm.. smh. Food was great, environment was great and service was good. Other than the fact our server forgot to place our initial appetizer order, was a good place.

4baLJEL-FTiklBrAJ0NNHQ.text: This was my first time my room mate and I tried Bangkok Balcony. We each got the green curry with pork, one a spicy level 0 and one a spicy level 4.   The curry was delicious! However the curry with a spicy level 0 was NOT a 0. I called to ask the restaurant if there was a possibility that they maybe made them both 4s or something and they said no. When I explained to them that the 0 shouldn't have been as spicy as it was, the woman on the phone told me, "that's just how Thai food is. It's all spicy."  I get Thai food a LOT. So much so that I'm surprised I haven't turned into a giant bowl of curry tbh. I'm talking twice a week on the regular. I've gotten curry at a spicy level 3 that was less spicy than their 0! When I explained to her that if I ordered a spicy level 0 I should have at least been informed that it was still going to be as spicy as it was, she didn't want to hear any of it. She told me it would take forever for them to remake it for me and deliver it to me again (I got delivery) which I was fine with, as long as I got food the way I wanted it. When I said I was okay with that, it turned out that she wasn't okay with it.   She then tried to completely deter me from getting the order remade. She said their curry is automatically a spicy level 3 and that they can't make it a 0. Why didn't you tell me this when I ordered a spicy level 0? She said I was supposed to assume that it was going to be spicy. Well, when I ordered a spicy level 0, I did not assume it was going to be a 3. That makes no sense.  Eventually someone else got on the phone, I'm assuming the manager, and told me they would remake the food and send it out to me no problem. I appreciated that, after verbally debating over my order with the first person I talked to on the phone.   I work in the service industry. I know how the cookie crumbles when it comes to these kinds of situations. I had to ask for half of my order refunded until they offered to remake it for me. That should have been their first go-to decision.   And lo and behold, the spicy level 0 was significantly less spicy than the one I first ordered. Who would have thought?

yWtLBUrDLRUJF8tS6AxGMQ.text: We stopped in for lunch on a Sunday. The restaurant was still quiet enough to hear the eclectic mix of Disney's Aladdin, ?Jewel, and soft R&B playing overhead. Service was good until the very end, when the waitress left me sitting with the bill waiting to pay. The food was excellent; I had the panang curry with beef, and he had the fried rice with pork. Plus, our entrees came with appetizers of soup, salad, and crispy roll. You know it's an upscale Asian restaurant when they have reusable (plastic) chopsticks rather than disposable ones. They even boxed up our leftovers for us. Word to the wise: if you only sorta like spicy food, 2/10 is plenty. 10/10 must be for fire-eaters!

S-79UaYct7FijwIoXTDaTg.text: Fail for me.  Our fave, Thai and Noodle Co is closed on Mondays. I knew of this place and daughter was fixated on kau soi. Which they didn't have so I should have walked out then, but we were there, and we'd both had a long day, we'd just moved the weekend before... Too tired.  They seem nice enough, and the soup is decent, but it was $26+ for a Sweetwater beer ($6), $14 for see-you noodles, and my Tom yum ($4.50)...and we'd had a minute discussion on my also wanting som tum. Back and forth, back and forth...   The space is nice and cool and fun; windows over Forbes. Up the stairs on this toasty afternoon was described as, "the desert," by my 7yo.  Lots of takeout whilst wee were there so your experience will hopefully be better. But there is just too, too much awesome food in that stretch for me to take another chance on this place. Malay, Taiwanese, hand tossed noodles and Chinese, and Szechuan not to far distant.  Bottom line: * Do we plan on returning? No.

Br9T6MV-GleApXz8gbKCAQ.text: Came here for a group dinner, and the service was impeccable! I got the Thai Sausage Fried Rice which was very tasty, but even better a few days later as leftovers. Two people in our party ordered the Green Curry and it looked amazing, will definitely have to try that next time.  I'm really interested in exploring more of the menu. We've been in the East End almost two years now and still haven't found our default take out place... I'm thinking we need to give Bangkok a try. Here's hoping!

oOpf6orHzo2wK0IhOHaKLQ.text: Good pad Thai, curry and lemon grass soup. Very good service. If you sit near the window, there is good view too!

xBTRn3Xc9uR6yiS1WO4_aw.text: This is my favorite Thai place in America! Their pineapple curry is something truly special!

SksD0lJE0fPO8iube4XrQw.text: I just got done here for lunch with my hubby lol we ordered shrimp toast, and mussaman curry. It was okay but they should have added more potatoes. The wine is great too. We were sitting by the big window and it was cute

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

djPUOQPfVvVLMJ3t8eqAsw.text: The menu says that the lunch special is only available on weekdays, but apparently they have it on weekends too (: For $8.95, I got the Panang Curry for my entree, with soup, a spring roll and salad as starters.   The soup they give you isn't like the soup you usually get in other lunch specials. The portion is bigger than usual and it also has little tofu bits in it too. I was pretty full before my entree came! Sadly, I didn't really like the Panang curry. It was a little too creamy and thick, and this kinda masked the curry taste. My friend also got the curry fried rice. Taste-wise, it was just okay, but he was shocked by the excessive amount of oil left on his plate after he finished his meal..   That being said, I would probably still come back to Bangkok Balcony for a cheap, mediocre Thai fix. Just don't expect too much when you come here.   PS: the window seats are great for people-watching (and lighting for photos ;) )

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States

Gp7sSAJ5hV5QRK01vlOTLQ.text: Good Atmosphere, reliable takeout, excellent choices of Thai Curries. Normally, I order takeout from Bangkok Balcony as seating inside can be hard to get in my experience. It is a bonus if you are able to sit in front of the large plate glass windows they have overlooking Forbes Avenue, which makes it a great date spot. It has a slightly upscale interior and a full bar in the back. I love their panang curry.

nPViBeYo-2e-ZixghDHfjQ.text: Visited my brother here.  he said, Let's eat here'  "   ...I Said '  "No  . Isn't that where you  ordered for your company  for lunch , and you foundEggshells   in your pad see ew  ...  no... broever

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. . Isn&#39;t that where you  ordered for your company  for lunch , and you foundEggshells   in your pad see ew  ...  no... broev·er

kJoH9-oTS_zsUHVAbOq8mw.text: My favorite restaurant in Pittsburgh! I go pretty much once a week. It has a full bar, delicious food and it's not a very loud restaurant, which I appreciate. My only criticism is the boba tea is a bit odd. The strawberry flavor is somewhat gritty and doesn't blend well. Other than that, Bangkok Balcony has great food!

8H2oUYprJSET212IzR-Xsg.text: Beef with basil leaf and bell peppers is everything! All of the goodness and all of the flavor. This is hands down my favorite meal to get. Other items that I enjoy eating are the choo-chee and panang curry.  This is a fun place to come with friends and family. They get pretty busy but to me it's worth the wait.

N_tck4GLofq4iDO3JyHXyg.text: Good food. Attentive Service. Nice Atmosphere.   Bangkok Balcony is a great option for Thai food in Squirrel Hill.   On our most recent trip we started with the Spring Rolls. While these aren't the best I've ever had, they are fresh, crisp and tasty. I'm not sure how I feel about the rolls being served cut up (I'm used to getting the whole roll), but that doesn't effect flavor so I'm not that worried about it).   My standard is the Yellow Curry. Chicken and Sweet Potatoes stewed in a fantastic yellow curry sauce and served with rice. The chicken is always tender, while the sweet potatoes provide a great contrast to the wonderful curry sauce. If it weren't frowned upon, I'd probably lick my bowl.   My wife ordered from the Main Course menu - an item simply referred to as "Garlic". This Thai stir fry has chicken (your choice of meat) plus veggies in a garlic sauce and rice. The meal is light and simple, but still satisfying.   Overall the service was quite good. Servers were friendly and attentive, while also helpful with questions.   I will often do takeout (lunch or dinner), as the restaurant can get kinda crowded.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Yellow Curry. Fantastic!
