Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Fresh rolls

bPFTu7j0kUBXDyJkZrk8kQ.text: Amazing curries and unique decor - this place was perfect for a cozy winter dinner. Definitely a nicer Thai restaurant, there are cloth napkins, fancy silverware, and paper tablecloths. The service was great - they were attentive and helpful.   The whole restaurant is nicely decorated and there is a small bar toward the back. The coolest seating, though, is along the front window overlooking Forbes Ave. It's a pretty cool view, looking out OR in! The window seats are only tables for two, though. Good date spot!  We ordered several of the curry dishes - massaman and panang were my favorites. These dishes had a great coconut milk and fish sauce flavor - classic Thai tastes. The yellow curry was more like an Indian curry and made for great winter comfort food. We also tried the curry fried rice. The flavor was unique and I liked it better than typical fried rice - there were a lot of vegetables and tofu mixed in, so it could really be an entree itself. It was quite greasy though.   You can order all the dishes with a variety of protein options. Vegetarians should note that even if you order tofu or veggies, a lot of dishes probably have fish sauce. If that's a concern, they have a section of vegetarian meals on the menu!   They offer a spice level of 1-10, though a lot of the dishes with chili paste and curry are 3-4 spiciness to begin with. I like some heat, so 6 was the perfect amount for my panang curry. It was spicy, but I didn't have to drink a gallon of water or anything.   Definitely will come back here for a date night!

KJJlzKGjG42Y1OfyVYGvEA.text: We went to Bangkok Balcony for Thai food on Friday night and it was great. My husband has recently cut out gluten and Thai food can be hit or miss with him but the staff was good with ensuring that our food was gluten free.  We got the pad Thai and the Lemongrass noodles. The lemongrass noodles were similar to a dish I have gotten elsewhere known as Drunken noodle and it was delicious. My husband liked it so much that he ate half my dish. The pad Thai was also really good, it had just the right amount of peanut in it.

QnWPOisJ-locHvSC5aT2Lw.text: Great place to eat Thai food in Squirrel hill. It's on top of the building and if you get the table by the glass windows , you see a nice view from below . Food is good and well priced and service is good.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. View from the restaurant.
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Appetizer grilled scallops.
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. View from the street

WvWfDcBLN3Hcr8wdNqUMtg.text: I ordered through uber eats.  I was excited about trying a different Thai restaurant. We Ordered Pad Thai with shrimp and mixed vegetables with brown sauce. Pad Thai was way over cooked. The peanuts had a burnt taste to them and the shrimp was rubbery. Mixed vegetable was ok but thought the portion size could have been a larger. Way overpriced for the quality and portion size. I had better Thai food for half the price. Sad that we had a bad experience because other reviews say otherwise.  Maybe its better if you eat in?

E6OPQiI-FJnBfuC0d-tTLg.text: Cozy place perched above Forbes in squirrel hill.  Bangkok gives you your typical selection of Thai food, and delivers consistent and tasty food across its menu.  I had the crab rangoon, chicken cashew, and the lamb curry, and it was all very tasty! The meat is pretty juicy, and not overcooked like many other places often do. Portions aren't super big, so you might want to order more, but everything tastes good, wasn't too heavy, and paired well with one another. The crab rangoon wasn't great thiugh, as it was essentially a fried chip with sauce inside, and not much meat.   I also got a Thai iced tea, and it was pretty nice.  I really liked the service here---waiters were very fast and nice about questions and giving recommendations for food. I will definitely come back to try some of their other menu items.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Crab rangoon
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Lamb curry
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Thai iced tea

LdYeNcY4AFvC3m8PM5dMHQ.text: I really like this place, the view from the dinner table, the staff, the good food, all add up to a reliable experience.  I've tried several dishes here but really like the soups and the way they cook the more traditional dishes.  This is a place I stop in whenever I'm in the neighborhood for work.

iAkATCXvPfFJob7K79QYkQ.text: I promised that if we finally had dinner here vs lunch and it was good I'd update to 4 stars.   Well we went here last night after drinks at HH and I have to say I was very happy with the results.   We had pad Thai and drunken noodles. We asked for both to be gluten free which pad Thai normally should be but drunken noodles often aren't. They said that was no problem.   The pad Thai was the best of the four Squirrel Hill Thai joints in my opinion. I've had the other three in the past month to compare and here's my take on the pad Thai here compared to the others:  1) it's saucier in a good way 2) the noodles are consistent and cooked well, not too chewy and not falling apart 3) the bean sprouts were cooked in not raw on top 4) there was ample peanut 5) the portion was large  The other Thai places miss one or two of those items above.  The drunken noodle was very good as well. And I can confirm that I have reason to believe they really were GF.   I've made my decision, for Thai in SQHill it's gonna be Bangkok Balcony Thai!

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Pad Thai, awesome!!

aNAwnD_TMaJJxZK7jjbLHQ.text: My work ordered some food from them for an office lunch. I tried the Pad Thai and the Massaman Curry. Both were top notch and I can't wait to try the restaurant in person.

VpsJdsOPdLpcZfZv8ifpOA.text: Good food good hospitality, you should def try it if you are around sq hill! Best Thai food so far!!!

8hPDMyWkFN74Jatrc1uF2w.text: Avoid this abomination at all costs. It is by far the worst Thai restaurant in Pittsburgh.   The shrimp in the Pad Thai was severely undercooked and the "fresh rolls" were devoid of any flavor.   We ordered delivery and the food arrived with our coconut soup with mushrooms exploded at the bottom of the bag.   Bangkok Balcony offered to replace the meal the next day and, lo and behold, the soup exploded again.   I will never order from them again and strongly suggest you steer clear of this place. There are so many better Thai restaurants in town.

QVy7AK9GY9zxSX9Uwrm5zg.text: I really enjoyed this place! It's a super cute area and gets you a lovely view of the street. The waitstaff was very friendly and overall, we had a pleasant time here.   The taste and presentation of the food were great! We ordered the chicken satay appetizer and it came with 2 delicious sauces. The Thai iced tea was a bit too sweet but still yummy and came in a beautiful V-shaped glass. For entrees, our party got the duck curry, seafood banquet and tofu garlic stir fry dish. They each came with rice and every single thing was finished.   That leads me to a few cons: -entree portions were small. It took no effort to finish everything on our plates even with the rice. The rice was also delicious but came in the tiniest bowls. More, please! -no spice level personalization. On their menus, it clearly displays a spice level of 0-10. I asked for zero spice in my duck curry and to have hot sauce or chili oil on the side. The waiter said the minimum spice level is 3. WTF? But when my father in law and husband ordered, they each asked for 2 and the waiter was accommodating. Is it because I'm Asian so they automatically assume I should be able to handle more? What is this? -prices weren't too high but for the portions, they were kind of high. Entrees ranged between 13-18 and appetizers were 6-10.

vRoXO-PcybMCHbqhIwRC1g.text: Was drawn by the cool street view, but don't let that fool you.  Service was terrible.  Sat at the table for ten minutes before water was brought out.  Then waited an additional ten minutes to place our order.... an additional ten minutes to wait for our wine to be brought out and ten more minutes for our food to be brought out with an ingredient we asked to be taken out.  Overall the food was boring and was not authentic and WAY over priced for the tiny portion.  It reminded me of mall food court quality.  Will never return because of the extremely long wait and mediocre food.

09ho7K4sciaDaTjQv-Daeg.text: This restaurant has good view of Forbes Ave in Squirrel Hill. Service was good. Server did ask about our spice level. Should were perfect. I had the pad Thai. It was OK. A little drier than how I like it. Overall, a good experience.

MQaWA_YMA2KLUa5T0RAgZg.text: Right in the heart of Pittsburgh's Squirrel Hill neighborhood, this second floor restaurant offers up a wide variety of really good Thai dishes. Everyone in your party will be sure to find something they like, even if it's just some good old chicken Pad Thai. They are very flexible with spice level, so don't worry if you don't have much of a tolerance for spicy foods. The full bar and nice view make Bangkok Balcony a great date night restaurant! I've always had a positive service experience with the staff, no issues there at all.

j4jR9HhU6FiJuACfxmnOew.text: I asked for an 8 on the spice scale but they looked at my American face and gave me a 0. I won't be going back.

6CRJ71EgewpVIBnXCq4GpQ.text: After further review, this placed sortof sucks.  I came again, by myself this time. ( I am not ashamed.  I actually enjoy it.)  The crab rangoon was obviously frozen.  It was cold inside.  If I'm going to eat something bad for me, I want it to be good!  Then I had a shrimp lettuce wrap thingy.  I don't know what it's called.  I was trying to be healthy by getting my vegetables in.  The idea of it is that the ingredients are wrapped in lettuce & you eat it like a burrito.  I chose the wrong thing, clearly.  It was iceburg lettuce.  Way to not only over-charge me, but then be a cheapass & give me the crappiest, cheapest lettuce.  I was not happy.  At all.  I also got a $7 mango mojito, which was ok...not fantastic.  All & all I spent $24 on something I could've made at home, & I am confident that I could've done a better job than them.

YDB3Lq0fSNbQRJadwqEQLA.text: Went there at 8pm on a Friday night. Curry was okay, appetizers not so fresh, and the soft shell crab with basil was horrible. That stuff must have been sitting in the back of the freezer for ages.   The place was half empty, but the server did her best to rush us out. We were barely finished our food and she came over and asked if we wanted it wrapped up. She took it and came back with our food in a bag, and dropped the check on the table. Didn't even bother to offer us dessert or ask how the food was.

5QJUStKkd5vXEBl2m3vdKA.text: Bangkok Balcony and Silk Elephant are owned by same person. Since I'm a big fan of Silk Elephant, I had a very high expectation before my visit. Indeed, nice environment, friendly servants, and good price, especially $8.25 lunch specials. However, there aren't as many choices available on the menu and the bar is much smaller. I did enjoy my visit this time, but will definitely go for Silk Elephant next time when I'm craving for Thai foods!

3Yq-s6jngSsVzo13uYiplw.text: Had a nice dinner here on a Sunday evening and was surprised that the restaurant provided live entertainment in the form of Thai dancers. All the food we ordered was delicious, especially the pumpkin curry which had nice large chunks of pumpkin in it. As this restaurant is located on the second story, the best seats are near the window looking out over Forbes Avenue. The people sitting at the table next to us ordered a whole fish which was somewhat alarming to look at but apparently tasty to eat! No complaints really, highly recommended.

bxIaYT7-Ey7QdRBYEh3m8A.text: A little overrated on the scale of Thai restaurants in Pittsburgh.  I'm a much bigger fan of Thai Place in Shadyside (plus there's shopping in the area! Who can turn down shopping?!)  I find it very inconsistent.  Sometimes the experience will be great.  Sometimes it just plan sucks.

Dv9BxpSsgu3awXkODJ9Biw.text: We have been here a bunch of times. Every time the service and food are great. The drinks are also tasty.

kQcUunfwxytx92sK9q6qSw.text: Best Thai in the city. Great service, fresh food and now delivery!

83KKzLdn077PWWEWipSN7A.text: Sort of biased - ha, but great thai food, and conveniently located on Forbes in Squirrel Hill. Their spicy levels are very precise on a 1-10 scale, though it doesn't get real spicy, and their curries are very good. I think the pad thai is probably slightly better at Silk Elephant - but they are owned by the same people and so that likely varies with the chef for the evening.

9W5Q-ezQ8edMDKBb4SBhwQ.text: The ambiance in this place isn't bad and neither is the food.  But that's the problem.  Their food is pretty average and not something I'd expect from a restaurant.  I could throw together their curries easily enough at home.  When you add in the difficulty of finding a place to park in Squirrel Hill and how crowded it can get, I would suggest eating elsewhere.  If you want amazing Thai food maybe go to Bloomfield instead.

0jEWGHLk8KHtUElet256lA.text: Bangkok Balcony has the BEST Yellow Curry I've ever had in my life. The END!

iSMA-QhJbnulfRCQGDT4Eg.text: It was only the second time in my life eating Thai, but I highly recommend this restaurant. I had a plate of mixed tempura veggies. Really delicious and it came with some sort of dipping sauce, which was great a compliment. For dinner I had a chicken curry bowl with green vegetables. You choose what spiciness level you want on an interval scale, from 1-10. I enjoy spicy foods and 6 was a perfect heat. I think any hotter would have affected the taste in a poor way. Anyway, the meal was delicious. Tender chicken and crisp vegetables in a curry/milk bowl. Moderately priced at about 12 dollars for a huge bowl of food. Appetizer was about $7-8. The wait staff was excellent as well.

s_WUPHWHFWny5s-5fpqbmA.text: Average at best (by my standards - thai classic back home in chicago blows this place away) but Id have to say the best thai I have had in Pittsburgh - thats why I gave it the extra star.    I judge all my thai food by 1 dish - Panang and this was good but nothing that left me wanting more - may not even order it again from here.  Wife had a tofu dish with basil and eggplant - had good flavor.    Dining room is nice and a little more up-scale.  Still a little over priced but for some reason - dining in Pittsburgh in general is overpriced for the quality and quantity of food.  $40 for 2 entrees, a chicken satay and we picked it up as I dont think they offer delievery.    Portions are average to small but that also seems par for Pittsburgh.  I would go back and would not hesitate to take an out of town guest here.    spicy is on a scale of 1 -10.  I went 5 so I could share my dish... I would say 8 is still being safe if you are looking to share with somone who does not like spicy food.  They dont seem to use chili paste but rather red pepper flakes.  They also have a bar which is a plus.

sllLw58qF1q69siPvVNENg.text: Average thai food, nothing really impressive, fairly expensive for what you get, typical below average thai restaurant in Pittsburgh.    One good thing, at least they have some sort of asian wait staff

Jyrc0X0UHF2u9C9yr4XDTQ.text: Awesome lunch special. $7.95 for a generous entree portion and salad. The curry is pretty good.

YMcX9BwzIUantSvAyWH4fA.text: placed a to go order here last night and our order was ready when i arrived.  mind you i drove all the way from the other side of town just to eat thai food that i knew wouldn't dissappoint.  i had the pineapple chicken thai curry dish.  generally speaking, i dislike peas but they are a nice add to this dish.  spice level was a 7.  absolutely delicious!  my boyfriend opted for the chicken cashew dish which included broccoli.  we both ate every last bite.  we're both fans of the place.  it was good getting it to go too.  it did seem a little pricey being just short of $30 total for both dishes.  it's worth it though- get that thai food fix!  oh and they do deliver now- they had a sign in the window......

BV70RpAF6NHg-32CMYksrw.text: This is what a dinner out should feel like. The food was interesting, but when I ordered Pad Thai I got a Pad Thai I recognized. Even though we were in the middle of the room, I could hear my dinner partners. Service was fast and courteous. The missing star is because there was nothing exceptional in my meal--it was good, solid, nicely prepared and served Thai food that I could expect to find in any mid-sized city in the U.S.

FR0M336Cz7wa-g_iwrb--Q.text: Bangkok is pretty good. Living in Squirrel Hill, it's one of the nicer nearby restaurants ambiance-wise, and their menu is quite extensive. I've enjoyed everything I've gotten there, the portions are rather large, and their specials are usually very tempting. I will say their alcoholic beverages are on the pricier size, but not bad.

iIslvR1P5bCgmOQzghvJiA.text: Went today to have lunch with my husband and daughter since it was a holiday.  Now it was a Monday at lunch.  My daughter does not like Thai food and Five Guys is a treat for her. We clearly walked in with her burger and after 15 minutes and when our appetizer was served, our waitress stated "No outside Food".  Now, if they had told us that upon entry, I would have understood. They do not have a children's menu or any Amercain food.  We were not there for dinner and it was after the ususal lunch rush.   I wanted my daughter to finish her burger and then sit quietly but the waitress was quite rude and told us no outside food again.  We got up and left and too bad they have lost good paying customers in this ecomomy.  We have done this all over the country with our daughter, hopeful she will enjoy Mom's "smelly food". We traveled 30 minutes to get Thai Food and will never go again.  BAD customer service. We got up and left!

gPvklUTIlbZl38qAD3g6rw.text: This is a great Thai place where you can easily share an entree between two people.  Service is quick and the food is tasty.

I-kTtswnfYQh99I6dbFdRA.text: Good.... didn't know quite what to order. The menu was a bit daunting, seeing as I've had Thai food only twice before in my life. Still, my friend wanted to go, and I got some tasty fried rice and and very good french martini. Definitely a good place to eat.

NqJ-2hO26EfzLIvYciRYMA.text: Having eaten in many Thai restaurants in New York recommended by my Thai friends, at first I didn't expect much from Bangkok Balcony. But I was proven wrong the minute I was seated by a very attentive and kind waiter.   We ordered green curry with chicken, grilled beef, and steamed rice. The food arrived in a timely manner and they were delicious! I wouldn't say that they were the best Thai food I've ever had, but I really enjoyed them. There's the spiciness level, and we chose an 8 I think. It wasn't  spicy at all for me :p The waiter offered us some chili sauce, which made the meal even tastier. We only ordered 1 steamed rice, and it was certainly plenty for my husband and I.   We went there for dinner, around 6pm. By the time we left the place (8ish), the place was practically full. Everyone dining seemed happy; a good sign, no? I would definitely go here again!

zmyko6Ykg9sSVXpwlssiDw.text: Overpriced and under seasoned.....I tried the coconut soup with shrimp spice level 5 and the basil leaf with chicken spice level 7. For what its worth the coconut soup was only marginally better than the basil leaf mainly because I could at least tell that they attempted to season it. The shrimp however were way overcooked to the point of being rubbery and there were only 3 of them in the soup. Next the basil leaf was only "hot" when the temperature of the food was; so much for the spice levels. It had no flavor at all and tasted like cheap chinese food which is unfortunate because the dish was not cheap. There you have it $20+ wasted on garbage. Dine at your own risk. If you are looking for Thai food I strongly recommend The Green Mango instead.

ddrHFisJ5BD2pIjxpzVwMw.text: Best Thai food in Pittsburgh. Eaten in and ordered takeout a bunch of times here. Loved the ambiance of the place.. excellent place to dine with friends.

Dhu2JeOO0NKIp1A50YkMkA.text: Very cool decor and a nice spot to peoplewatch if you sit by the window. But the part of Forbes between Murray and Shady must be cursed with untasty food spell (ice cream and donuts not included). I tried the egg rolls (tiny!), tofu fried rice (eeeh, I make better tofu at home and I suck), and fried banana and coconut ice cream (YUM! for ice cream, banana - eh)  With this, I give up reviewing Pittsburgh restaurants because I don't want to sound like Debbie Downer in ALL my reviews.

D18CCjsTTKgRtksAln81Yg.text: AWFUL service, great food. We had a large group for a birthday (for which a reservation was made) and we went to the bar for all of our drinks including water and pop. We enjoyed the food but upon asking for extra rice for leftovers, I was told that would be a $3 charge. I did share the bowl with someone (no NOT the meal), thankfully I knew the person.  It took 40 minutes to get our bill which we had to split yet again with my rice partner and her husband.  We had to put more money in the meter that we already put money in for 3 hours. We added more money and escaped 3 minutes before getting a ticket.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. &#34;Rice partners&#34;. Dont ask for your own bowl...$3!

TxvRBkQSwqAdmfgPBijPcw.text: Hands down the BEST pad thai I've tried in my entire life.   It was my first time having pumpkin curry, but I don't think anything could top the experience here. Chunks of soft, buttery pumpkin with a light coconut milk-infused curry sauce. I wanted to lick the plate when I was done.  Nice decor, service was quick and polite, and this place is open late. What more could a college foodie ask for?

GIaL7W5EYOcJ9QlcwubwRA.text: A bit pricey for dinner, but their lunch specials are great!  For ~$12 (lunch) you get a spring roll, a little salad and your entree.  Everything I have tried here is really good, but my favorite is the pad see eu.  The wonton soup is quite good as well.  Once I had pumpkin curry, which was also amazing.   I also believe they have started to deliver.   Highly recommended!

_a4-pX2s5evDWnFAR1VOoQ.text: Ermm honestly I have had better Thai before this place has good ambience, good service, staff are nice but the food not so much. Me and husband are food lovers and we definitely love our Thai but we were so disappointed on the food I had the flat noodle in their "special" gravy with shrimp which according to me was not so specially it lacked so much in terms flavor and "specialness" a total let down and I mean it I barely ate anything off of that humongous dish they served with sauce pouring down every which way so I thought of having the shrimp which of course you would expect to be deveined if you're getting food in a restaurant but no the shrimp had vein in them which pretty much grossed me out. Then moving on I thought "let me finish the mushrooms at least since I haven't eaten anything" I promise the mushrooms didn't have any flavor or seasoning whatsoever it was a piece of rubber in my mouth. The reason I love Thai is flat noodles! But j hardly had any noodles there was just a few pieces of noodles floating in the huge dish of tangy and sour "special" sauce and carrots. That's about my dish. My husband ordered the lemongrass noodle with chicken as well know lemongrass itself has an amazing aroma and flavor and in addition to that if you add Napa basil the aroma and flavor would be irresistible but nope! We had to be disappointed the there was no aroma, no flavor and let alone the seasoning and the chicken was so bland I can't even imagine the good thing about my husband's dish was it had noodles unlike mine. I am upset that I didn't get to enjoy their food like everyone else here on yelp.

mLDMzxuwTueCM0oB3GCLhg.text: I had the best Pumpkin curry of my life last night at the Balcony. Thank you! :)

ciTegsasfXDOj1gjgnL5Pw.text: I love Thai food and have been coming here since my undergrad days. I must admit, however, that after trying several dishes on the menu, I just keep gravitating back to the Lemongrass noodles with tofu. Everything else feels sub par after you've had that one!   The Thai iced tea is great but overpriced. The servers are always courteous, which I cannot say of the bar staff. Overall, this is one of my favorite restaurants in the burgh.

r9cfkkB3O4ZantltyL-nYQ.text: Place use to be better but after new management came in, dishes weren't as good as they use to be.  The food is good, but with the price tag and the portion they give you, it really is just ok.  There are better options for Thai food in the area.

A0dL0HZCU_W0L2YorsifKg.text: The worst Thai food I've had in Pittsburgh. The service was slow, but expected for a Friday night. Wait staff is friendly. Restaurant is noisy when crowded. The food was a big disappointment. We had the fish in ginger sauce and mixed seafood with basil leaves. The fish was overcooked, the scallops in the mixed seafood dish had gone bad, and neither dish was tasty. What do others see in this restaurant?

rmUIxMmsfKvyCb789bFB5w.text: Very stylish restaurant with a great street view. Food can be on the spicier side here which is a plus. Worth checking out based on the price point.

MOWiAa45vUVF4ZdvwLSnNw.text: Tasty food but too Americanized. Menu does not read actual Thai dish names, food is not very spicy (ordered a 7/10 and barely tasted any spice at all- maybe the equivalent of a 3-4/10 at any other Thai restaurant).

qNUFax9keyPtc8hdg7341A.text: So good.  The location is pretty cool on the second floor of a building in Sq. Hill. The food was great and so was the service. Pumpkin Curry and Drunken Noodles were great.

r19L8fa7FyFH9dMYp_1JYg.text: This is a solid, middle-of-the-road Thai restaurant.  If you're craving Thai food, this place will probably satisfy, but it's nothing special.  I've had their Crab Rangoons (very good), Veggie See-You Noodles (mediocre), and Veggie Pad-Thai (mediocre).

W7KtOfI3c5ll9EBYaqDpiw.text: Best lunch deal in the 'Burgh! Meal includes a salad, miso soup, and a spring roll, along with an entree, for $8.50! The food is delicious and fresh, and the service has always been great. I've also had food delivered before and have always been impressed with the quality and freshness of the food. My favorites include the fresh spring rolls, green curry with tofu, and lemongrass noodles.

YrdhKIU2xYB0IZbEeBaKAQ.text: Love the food, perfect price range, and I really love the yellow duck curry. The way they mix cocoanut into the curry just blends in so perfectly. Good for large groups to romantically dining with two, it's really an amazing place.

qS1zeVfscBBachUudf_L_Q.text: This is the first Thai place I've ever been to in my life so this place holds a special place in my heart.  I probably went here for every birthday that I had in Pittsburgh.  I think either my friends are too lazy to find a new place or they know that I'll like it anyways haha.   This place is great for groups!  Really nice, loungey environment, bustling yet nice intimate lighting and quiet enough to have deep conversations with the person next to you.    My favorite dish is the chicken pad thai (yea i know) and I usually get a 5 on the spicy scale.  I believe if you LOVE spiciness you can ask them to go off the scale all the way up to 15 (instead of 10).  The soft shell crab here is also quite good.  I've tried other dishes like pad see ew, green curries (mmm good) and their appetizers and everything is pretty good.  I've never had a bad time here.

VFh-IC6zJlmHdjGSPNPBzw.text: I ordered the deep fried tofu appetizer and the hawmok seafood entree. At first the waitress thought it was an appetizer and I had to show her the menu where it was listed as an entree. The tofu dish tasted good. However, I was not at all impressed with the entree in terms of appearance, portion, or taste. It was wrapped in tin foil (which I knew going in) to preserve flavors, and the inside was also then wrapped in lettuce. To me it didn't look that appealing or exotic. It didn't taste terrible but it wasn't to die for and the portion was pretty small. The bill pretty much topped it off. Although the staff was pleasant and did well enough accommodating the large party, when you have food that doesn't look or taste great, is not a decent portion size (at least compared to other like restaurants in the area), and to top it off is pricey, then there is less incentive to express a positive viewpoint or to give it another chance.

ZhQwBzvcOLJ2x8YBf5Gipw.text: An ex-gf and I used to walk here from her apt. down the street and it was a good pad thai they did.  Then they had the fire and were closed for along time .  I have heard they will refuse to seat 1 person (if you're alone.)  I don't like this policy at all .   Owned by same guy who owns Silk Elephant, around the corner on Murray Ave. Portions are on the small-side .  Interesting interior decor and very colorful .

Gy144_PEXlKRDLLwbULyww.text: Bangkok Balcony is probably one of the nicest eateries in the Squirrel Hill area as far as atmosphere, view, and spaciousness goes.  I'm not entirely sure that fancy chopsticks and a tasteful decor make up for the priciness of the food.  The awesome service may somewhat balance it out I suppose.  While tasty, the food lacked in spiciness despite the fact that my Partner In Cuisine and I ordered a 9 and an 8 respectively.  I also felt the portions were rather small considering the price we were paying for noodles.  I think that we'll return on occasion, but at those prices, I don't think we'll ever be considered "regulars."

SnJFCUpbZ5_YM0IA3ddYLA.text: The food was ok. But the service was disappointing, we came at 1pm on a Saturday, it wasn't too busy, 6 tables two servers.  The server didn't give us water until I asked for it. At the end, servers were talking in the front for a long time before she handed the check.

Isnb4JeEsxg6MXHUQjaB7g.text: Pad thai here has some smoked flavor that tastes awesome. We substituted tofu for thai lettuce wrap that was awesome too. Only thing didn't like was the tofu toast said toasted but were deep fried and did NOT like it. Good service. Moderate sized portions.   I would recommend it.

7oZG89VGE4rXVc9bGUhKDw.text: I dined here last night with a friend and was excited to get a small table at the window overlooking Forbes-which was great. The food in general is overpriced for the dishes and quality. I got a green curried tofu dish, which was pretty good, but cost almost 15 bucks. I chose a spiciness of 6 and it was perfect, although if I come here again I'd bump it up to a 7 or 8. The staff was all very friendly and the service was great. Overall, though, run-of-the-mill Thai place in Pittsburgh.

-ACA03P-L5CRsES-AX8r4w.text: This was the second visit to this Thai restaurant, the first was some years ago. Three of us stopped for dinner. Seating was not a problem. The meal was just ok. the appetizers were disappointing. The fresh rolls had a sticky and thick rice wrap and mostly pale lettuce. Dumplings fair. The dinner curry was good, as was the beef salad. But a noodle dish was not visually appealing and reported to be "just OK". The server was attentive. The beer selection and prices were fine. I would go to Pusadee's where the rolls are delicate and full of fresh herbs and the dumplings are beyond compare.

KiIoISDJ7gEJmQgzGA3F1w.text: Another worthy member of Pittsburgh's fantastic Thai scene, the Bangkok Balcony doesn't disappoint.  It's a little pricey, but the atmosphere is wonderful; the staff is competent; and the food is good.  The pumpkin curry is an especially fantastic fusion delicacy, and having unsuccessfully tried to replicate it at home, I keep coming back for the good stuff.

P9fWdI7bpX_F-2A3vkLq_g.text: Food is ok but service is always very good. Price is on the high side

a2kbH-OIpYMhjg0VdT-VCQ.text: Had an excellent coconut milk free curry. Really enjoyed.

DiY_qf8ysSydt9auC0OtWw.text: This place is consistently good. I love the fish with chili sauce. I was craving the steamed dumplings but I have a shellfish allergy and you can't get them with pork alone here.  They mix the pork and shrimp so I had to pass (disappointing). Also, found out they do have drunken noodles but in the menu it's called lemongrass noodles.

giPjCmKD3bEPxpeGZAsxjg.text: This is the probably best Thai restaurant I have found in Pittsburgh - the Tofu Mussaman Curry is fantastic and the spring rolls are always worth it as well. Never had a bad meal here!  It's on the second floor of a building on Forbes Ave in the heart of Squirrel Hill, and if you get a seat near the big glass windows you get a nice view of the hustle and bustle below. It has a great ambience and the staff has always been friendly.  The reason I deduct a star - last time I was there with a friend who is also a vegetarian, we ordered a tofu pad thai and found a few small pieces of chicken in it. Probably an understandable mistake, but still sort of unnerving. The service and the food was otherwise great, so we didn't make a fuss about it.

2l-dX7tt_bswkb7R1q-1PQ.text: Best Thai food that I have ever had! The good was amazing.  We had the dumplings, crab ragoons, and pad thai.  The food had great tast. The waitress was very attentive. The mood was relaxing.  There were candles and it looked over looked the street.  Sit by the window, you won't regret it.

9FM-MacFwQ-GzRNDlW0oQw.text: My lunch was excellent as I'd expect sinxe the same owners have Bangkok Balcony and Silk Elephant. As my waitress pointed out, ther are different chefs, so there are amall variations in the items. I enjoyed  sitting by the window on a nice sunny day.

jqcO1vjWB9p_pl3UsjSUdg.text: Bangkok Balcony = nom.  I've never eaten in here, but I've gotten take out twice and it was awesome both times.  We ordered a ton of food to feed five of us last week, and still enjoyed a few days of leftovers.  We got..... -Thai Spring Rolls (some with chicken, some with shrimp, some veg) - all crunchy and delish. -Coconut Soup (my boyfriend likes it, I didn't try it) -Pad Thai  -See You Noodles -Mussaman Curry -Panang Curry  And everything was really good.  The curries were a huge hit - I loved the mussaman, but everyone else was raving about the panang.  The see-you noodles (Pad See Ew, essenially) were delish, that's one of my favorite standards.  It's pricey, for Thai....well, it's pricey for take out Thai.  Back in Chicago, my boyfriend and I were happily living in the land of $7 curries, and the idea of paying $14 for curry was ridiculous.  I'm bummed that there is no cheaper Thai place near us, so we don't go to Bangkok Balcony as much as I'd like to.  But when parents are in town, or if you want to sit down and really have a dining experience, I think it's worth it.  And it's really high quality and delicious so that makes the price more justifiable.  Sort of.

jjrbTg_xLsugBow7qnlCew.text: Excellent!!! This was the BEST food we have had since being in NYC last November.  I I has the Sweet and Sour Chicken and my husband had the Three Taste Fish. Definitely would come back to Pittsburgh just to eat here. But, as a side note the entrance is up a steep flight of stairs. I didn't see any handicap entrance. Please update post I anyone knows of handicap access.

photos.caption: Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Three Taste Fish
Photo of Bangkok Balcony - Pittsburgh, PA, United States. Sweet and Sour Chicken

uSCggxaALPh182y-pQivmg.text: Ordered chicken pad thai and the thai wonton soup. Definitely had better. For the price, was disappointed. Still trying to find a really good Thai place in this city.

7RtkIgi-wMu3Nm3fzU6M_g.text: I liked their pumpkin curry. Frankly, of all the restaurants that deliver curry(Thai or Taiwanese), I liked this the best. I'm giving four stars because I found them to be a little expensive for their portions.

8La1sa_uu_z8n57j2opL2w.text: My friend and I went there last Saturday night. Parking, as always, was a little tricky, but we found a spot right across the street from the place. It was filled at around 8 when we came in, but we just had to sit at the bar for about 15 minutes and we were shown to a table right by the window.   Definitely try the Thai Iced Tea with coconut milk(?), it's excellent. We started off with the wonton soup, which was really good; there were a lot of good vegetables in it. I had the Panang Curry with pork and I couldn't get enough of it. For every meal, you have to pick how spicy you want it to be on a scale of 1-10. I did a 1, and it was mildly spicy but not bland or anything. The atmosphere was warm and inviting and out waitress was very attentive. The food came quickly for how busy it was. There was no loud music or anything like that. I've been coming here since I was about 12 years old, and it's still my favorite place in Pittsburgh for Asian/Oriental food. Lunch is great, too.

8IitidBOe2wfvUsVQ8m6eQ.text: The best Thai food in the city.  This Squirrel Hill gem and its sister restaurant Silk Elephant, which offers more small plate options, both offer authentic cuisine and wonderful service. I love their pumpkin curry. And be sure to order their black rice on the side for a delicious alternative to the bland, run-of-the-mill white variety- trust me!

AwJoc88uBME9NGDk9KsJ-w.text: Food is really great! I had a nice birthday there with a cake from cold stone. Just the waiting time is too long...
